text: As an art historian I am a disciple of Heinrich Wolfflin. In our
label: Paragraph

text: personal contacts with him as well as through his distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: lectures, we, his pupils, learned to grasp the spirit of an epoch.
label: Paragraph

text: Wolfflin’s incisive analysis made clear to us the true meaning
label: Paragraph

text: and significance of a painting or a piece of sculpture.
label: Paragraph

text: He delighted in contrasting one period with another. He em-
label: Paragraph

text: ployed this method most effectively both in his teaching and
label: Paragraph

text: in his books —in his Renaissance and Baroque (1889), in
label: Paragraph

text: Classical Art (1899), in which the fifteenth century is opposed
label: Paragraph

text: to the sixteenth, and even in his Principles of Art (Kunst-
label: Paragraph

text: geschichtliche Grundbegriffe, 1915), which had just appeared
label: Paragraph

text: when I studied under him at Munich. Many of his pupils have
label: Paragraph

text: tried to emulate this method of contrasting styles, but none
label: Paragraph

text: have achieved the same depth and directness.
label: Paragraph

text: In my own first book, Late Baroque and Romantic Classicism
label: Paragraph

text: (Munich, 1922, written as a thesis), I tried to follow Wolfflin’s
label: Paragraph

text: method. The periods contrasted were the end of the eighteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century and the beginning of the nineteenth, both periods of
label: Paragraph

text: classicism. The Louis X VI style formed in shape and structure
label: Paragraph

text: the end of late baroque tendencies, with classicism serving as
label: Paragraph

text: its framework. The classicism of the beginning of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century found its most significant outlet in that country
label: Paragraph

text: of romantics, Germany. In the architecture of the time the
label: Paragraph

text: trend toward an individualistic isolation of rooms from each
label: Paragraph

text: other was nowhere so strongly marked as it was in Germany —
label: Paragraph

text: in the work of K. F. Schinkel, for example. This was the true
label: Paragraph

text: architectural equivalent of the individualism of the romantic
label: Paragraph

text: poets.
label: Paragraph

text: I called this period one of romantic classicism. Classicism in
label: Paragraph

text: both periods was only a coloring — a transitory fact, as I would

text: Heinrich Wélfflin was the pupil of Jakob Burckhardt, and

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: yersation. Thus the Swiss historical tradition formed the basis

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: later.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: THlistorians quile generally distrust absorption into contempo-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: detachment, dignity, and breadth of outlook. But one can be
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughly the creature of one’s own period, embued with its
label: Paragraph

text: methods, without sacrificing these qualities. Indeed. the
label: Paragraph

text: historian in every field must be united with his own time by
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: history, like the world of nature, explains itself only to Lhose
label: Paragraph

text: who ask the right questions, raise the right problems. The his-
label: Paragraph

text: lorian must be intimately a part of his own period to know
label: Paragraph

text: what questions concerning the past are significant to it.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from this approach, history remains a wilderness of
label: Paragraph

text: blank happenings in which no creative work is possible.
label: Paragraph

text: Only dead chronologies and limited special studies will be
label: Paragraph

text: produced. The historian detached from the life of his own time
label: Paragraph

text: writes irrelevant history, deals in frozen facts. But it is his
label: Paragraph

text: unique aud nontransferable task to uncover for his own age its
label: Paragraph

text: vital interrelalionships with the past.
label: Paragraph

text: The historian cannot in actual fact detach himself from the
label: Paragraph

text: life about him; he, too, stands in the stream. The ideal his-
label: Paragraph

text: torian — out of the press of affairs, au-dessis de la mélée, sur-
label: Caption

text: veying all time and all existence from a lofty pedestal — is a
label: Paragraph

text: fiction.
label: Paragraph

text: The historian, like every other man, is the creature of his Lime
label: Paragraph

text: and draws from it both his powers and his weaknesses. By
label: Paragraph

text: virtue of lus calling he may survey a larger circle of events
label: Paragraph

text: than his average conlemporary, bul this docs not lift him out of
label: Paragraph

text: his own historical selling. It is even to his advantage lo be
label: Paragraph

text: forced from his academic chair occasionally and made to
label: Paragraph

text: participate in Lhe common struggles of the moment. For direct
label: Paragraph

text: contact with life and its necessilies sharpens his abilities to
label: Paragraph

text: penetrate the jungle of printed records to the unfalsified voices
label: Paragraph

text: of the real actors.
label: Paragraph

text: It is the task of the historian to recognize the truth through
label: Paragraph

text: all its disguises.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately the historian has often used his office to pro-
label: Paragraph

text: claim the eternal right of a static past. He has gone further
label: Paragraph

text: and has used arguments based on past happenings to restrict
label: Paragraph

text: and distort the future.

text: ATY
label: Title

text: For planning of any sort our knowledge must go beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: state of affairs that actually prevails. To plan we must know
label: Paragraph

text: what lias gone on in the past and feel what is coming in the
label: Paragraph

text: future. This is not an invitation to prophecy but a demand
label: Paragraph

text: for a universal outlook upon the world.
label: Paragraph

text: At the present time the difficult field of town planning seems
label: Paragraph

text: to resist all handling. In times when a universal viewpoint

text: existed no genius was required to produce urban treatments of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: creation. Achievements brought about for a specific purpose
label: Paragraph

text: and # specific social class proved serviceable in a quite different
label: Paragraph

text: period for different purposes and different groups. This was

text: universal point of view.
label: Paragraph

text: Today the urge toward such universality is deeply felt by

text: evervone. It is the reaction against a whole century spent in

text: living from day to day. What we sce around us is the reckon-

text: To have a closer contact with history: in other words, to carry
label: Paragraph

text: on our lives ina wider time-dimension. Present-day happen-

text: ings are simply the most conspicuous sections of a continuum;

text: visible Lo the human cye.

text: The destructive confusion of events in the world at large today

label: Paragraph

text: being developed.
label: Paragraph

text: Everybody knows that we have far more means of bringing
label: Paragraph

text: change under farsighted control than any of the peoples of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of man’s ability to organize his own life.

text: CONTEMPORARY HISTORY
label: Title

text: A wider survey of the whole domain of human activity is the
label: Paragraph

text: unmistakable need of the century. It is in this connection that
label: Paragraph

text: history can play an important role. One of the functions of
label: Paragraph

text: history is to help us to live in a lafger sense, in wider dimen-
label: Paragraph

text: sions. This does not mean that we should copy the forms and
label: Paragraph

text: attitudes of bygone periods, as the nineteenth century did, but
label: Paragraph

text: that we should conduct our lives against a much wider histori-
label: Paragraph

text: cal background.
label: Paragraph

text: In the part of contemporary history we shall be concerned with,
label: Paragraph

text: the most important developments are the changes that have
label: Paragraph

text: come about in daily life.
label: Paragraph

text: The eternal complaint of the nineteenth century was that all
label: Paragraph

text: the dignity had gone out of ordinary life. And ordinary life
label: Paragraph

text: did lose its dignity from the moment it was put on an exclu-
label: Paragraph

text: ively day-to-day basis. People lost all sense of playing a part
label: Paragraph

text: st pistory: they were either indifferent to the period in which
label: Paragraph

text: jhey lived or they hated it. When they compared themselves
label: Paragraph

text: with the people of other periods their activities seemed unim-
label: Paragraph

text: portal stand without significance, either good or bad.
label: Paragraph

text: The same feeling produced an extreme disregard for the
label: Paragraph

text: immediate past — for contemporary history, Lhat is. Uncon-
label: Paragraph

text: sciously, jn their matter-of-fact constructions, the men of the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: which the future was to take its structure. They did not sce

text: this. however; indeed, it is sometimes not recognized today,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: but something still worse —- the wanton destruction of the
label: Paragraph

text: objects and the records which were essential to its understand-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. Later periods will be forced to leave great gaps in their
label: Paragraph

text: “accounts of the modes of existence of the nineteenth and

text: THE IDENTITY OF METHODS
label: Title

text: Our period is a period of transition. The tangle of different
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies continuing from the past or pointing to the future,
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies which mix confusedly and interpenetrate al every
label: Paragraph

text: point, makes our period seem to lack any definite line of
label: Paragraph

text: advance. To some it presents the appearance of a chaos of
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory impulses. An‘ eminent French sociologist wrote
label: Paragraph

text: recently that ‘ we see around us nothing save tumult, aimless
label: Paragraph

text: agitation, hesitant opinions, vacillating thoughts.”
label: Paragraph

text: We must not forget, however, that this particular transition
label: Paragraph

text: period has lasted fora whole century. It has made itself felt
label: Paragraph

text: in cach country at the same rate and in the same proportion
label: Paragraph

text: as the disorder which the process of industrialization produced
label: Paragraph

text: every where.

text: TRANSITORY AND CONSTITUENT FACTS
label: Title

text: It is not the historian’s task to tell the public what pleases or
label: Paragraph

text: displeases him personally. That is a private affair which loses
label: Paragraph

text: all its interest in the telling. The historian is not required to
label: Paragraph

text: correct an epoch in the light of his own opinions. Ile has to
label: Paragraph

text: explain it, to show why history took a certain direction. The
label: Paragraph

text: people who lived in a period can best tell us, out of their own
label: Paragraph

text: inner feelings, whelher its development was happy or unhappy.
label: Paragraph

text: The voices which come to us out of the fortunes or misfortunes
label: Paragraph

text: of an age furnish indispensable testimony. No man of a later
label: Paragraph

text: time, however great the impartiality which distance from the
label: Paragraph

text: events has brought, can approach Lhe direct and certain feeling
label: Paragraph

text: for a period which belonged Lo Lhose in the midst of the strug-
label: Paragraph

text: gle — a struggle which involved their destiny. Words uttered
label: Paragraph

text: out of the needs of the time are the historian’s real guides, and
label: Paragraph

text: itis from them that he must draw his explanation of the period.
label: Paragraph

text: The true critique of an age can only be Laken from the testi-
label: Paragraph

text: mony of that age.
label: Paragraph

text: Entirely objective judgment with no trace of personal bias is,
label: Paragraph

text: on the face of things, quite impossible. Nevertheless, the in-
label: Paragraph

text: filtration of the personal must be reduced to a minimum. The
label: Paragraph

text: historian is not solely a calaloguer of facts; it is his right, and
label: Paragraph

text: indeed his duty, to pass judgment. His judgments must, how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, spring directly from his facts.
label: Paragraph

text: The historian cannot speak with the direct authority of a con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary, but he has a breadth of outlook which the con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary inevitably lacks. He sees facts which were hidden
label: Paragraph

text: from the people of the time he studies. He can tell more or Jess
label: Paragraph

text: short-lived novelties from genuinely new trends. The facts of
label: Paragraph

text: history fall into one or the other of these classes, and it is the
label: Paragraph

text: business of the historian to distinguish accurately between
label: Paragraph

text: them.
label: Paragraph

text: Constituent facts are those tendencies which, when they are
label: Paragraph

text: suppressed, inevitably reappear. Their recurrence makes us
label: Paragraph

text: aware Lhat these are clements which, all together, are produc-
label: Paragraph

text: ing a new tradition. Constituent facts in architecture, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, are the undulation of the wall, the juxtaposition of
label: Paragraph

text: nature and the human dwelling, the open ground-plan. Con-
label: Paragraph

text: stituent facts in the nineteenth century are the new potentiali-
label: Paragraph

text: ties in construction, the use of mass production in industry,
label: Paragraph

text: the changed organization of society.
label: Paragraph

text: Facts of the other sort — equally the work of the forces moving
label: Paragraph

text: in a period — lack the stuff of permanence and fail to attach
label: Paragraph

text: themselves to a new tradition. At first appearance they may
label: Paragraph

text: have all the éclat and brilliance of a firework display, but they
label: Paragraph

text: have no greater durability. Sometimes they are interlaced
label: Paragraph

text: with every refinement of fashion — the furniture of the Second
label: Paragraph

text: Empire in France is an instance. These we shall call transitory
label: Paragraph

text: facts.
label: Paragraph

text: Transitory facts in their dash and glitter often succeed in tak-
label: Paragraph

text: ing over the center of the stage, This was the case with the
label: Paragraph

text: experiments in historical styles that went on — with infinite
label: Paragraph

text: changes of direction — throughout the whole nineteenth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury. The entire output of official painting was a Lransitory

text: fact of that period, almost wholly without significance to the

text: present day.

label: Paragraph

text: THE LATE BAROQUE
label: Title

text: The manner in which Renaissance modes shaded off into
label: Paragraph

text: baroque, the way in which the new shapes became more and
label: Paragraph

text: inmore evident until they were wholly transformed by the archi-

text: tects of the lale seventeenth century — all this is quite familiar.
label: Paragraph

text: In the hands of the baroque builders, the Renaissance shapes
label: Paragraph

text: were no more than the primilive elements of architectural com-
label: Paragraph

text: position. In just the way that Bach would transpose a simple
label: Paragraph

text: melody into a great new harmony, elaborate and subtle, these
label: Paragraph

text: architects transmuted the forms developed in the Renaissance.
label: Paragraph

text: The interiors they produced are marked by an inseparable
label: Paragraph

text: union of two kinds of interests usually encountered separately:
label: Paragraph

text: they are at once the products of purely mathematical specula-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of a high order of complexity, and completely visionary
label: Paragraph

text: or mystical imaginalive creations. The same union of two such
label: Paragraph

text: different spirils appears in the work of a baroque master of
label: Paragraph

text: another medium, Blaise Pascal (1623-1662). At sixteen he had
label: Paragraph

text: wrillen a classic work on conic sections; he went on to study
label: Paragraph

text: the cycloid curve, Lo develop the theory of probability, and to
label: Paragraph

text: do pioneer work in physical science. Pascal's religious mysti-
label: Paragraph

text: cism had its roots in such speculations. “ The eternal silence of
label: Paragraph

text: these infinite spaces terrifies me" comes out of his work on the
label: Paragraph

text: mathematical implications of infinity, and leads up to his feel-
label: Paragraph

text: ing for the insignificance of man without God.
label: Paragraph

text: The last phases of the baroque development are the true in-
label: Paragraph

text: heritance of the epoch out of which we grow. We shall have to
label: Paragraph

text: consider first the Italian products of the baroque era, and then
label: Paragraph

text: go on to see what the north of Europe adds to these results.
label: Paragraph

text: It may perhaps be advisable —- in view of the history of the
label: Paragraph

text: term — to offer the prefatory comment that “ baroque ” does
label: Paragraph

text: not apply exclusively to an overdecorated building in Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: or Spain. For more than fifty years the history of art has used
label: Paragraph

text: “baroque to designate the period beginning with Michel-
label: Paragraph

text: angelo and continuing until the eighteenth century, and even
label: Paragraph

text: beyond in some fields - - Lown planning, for example. “ Late
label: Paragraph

text: baroque ” would date a work as after 1660. The baroque age
label: Paragraph

text: lasted therefore about as long as the Gothic. [ts name, curi-
label: Paragraph

text: ously enough, has had much the same fale — thus * Gothic ”
label: Paragraph

text: up to the nineteenth century remained a synonym for Lhe
label: Paragraph

text: barbarous or the uncouth. Jn some contemporary English

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: baroque that begins with Michelangelo. The German archi-

label: Paragraph

text: Jate baroque of nearly all countries. More recently, the ex-

text: cellent. Viennese school of history has covered the late period

text: with great thoroughness. “ Baroque ~ has by now an accepted

text: imenning in the field of art history, as referring nol to a special

text: shape but lo a whole period.
label: Paragraph

text: The distinguishing mark of the baroque age is the method of

text: thinking and of feeling Lhat prevails in it; ils outstanding

text: feature is the development of a specific kind of universality.

text: In our field, this manifests itself as a new power to mold space,

text: and to produce an aslonishing and unified whole from the most

text: various parls. But itis worthy of note that, in all departments,
label: Paragraph

text: baroque methods and ways of [celing survive until the disinte-
label: Paragraph

text: gration produced by the industrial age sets in and brings with

text: ita lemporary destruction of the universal point of view.

text: THE ORGANIZATION OF OUTER SPACE
label: Title

text: The Residential Group and Nature
label: Title

text: The work of the baroque architects was both continued and
label: Paragraph

text: supplemented in France during the late seventeenth century,
label: Paragraph

text: French contributions appear especially in two fields: in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of more highly refined types of human residence,
label: Paragraph

text: and in the organization of outer space.
label: Paragraph

text: The decisive influence upon developments in France, which
label: Paragraph

text: had just become the leading European country, was the com-
label: Paragraph

text: plete supremacy of a secular government. Absolutism was in
label: Paragraph

text: the saddle, and, as a corollary, the personal life of the monarch
label: Paragraph

text: had become the center of all social life.
label: Paragraph

text: But in addition a new power was making itself felt, a power of
label: Paragraph

text: the greatest importance and one which did not affect the Ro-
label: Paragraph

text: man baroque: the feminine influence. The growing demand for
label: Paragraph

text: a better organization of human residences, for greater comfort,
label: Paragraph

text: commodité, was intensified by the novel importance of women
label: Paragraph

text: in French society. These two factors, of course, worked to-
label: Paragraph

text: gether. In 1665, for example, Louis XIV asked the Pope to
label: Paragraph

text: permit Lorenzo Bernini, his greatest architect, to come to
label: Paragraph

text: Paris and draw up a plan for the new Louvre. Bernini’s design
label: Paragraph

text: was rejected — with all possible politeness, of course, but not
label: Paragraph

text: because it was too theatrical, as the usual explanation has it.
label: Paragraph

text: An eighteenth-century architect. gives us the real reason:
label: Paragraph

text: Bernini ne pouvait se préter 4 entrer dans tous les details de
label: Caption

text: ces distributions, de ces commodités qui rendent le service
label: Paragraph

text: d’un palais commode.” In other words, Bernini failed to show
label: Paragraph

text: a grasp of the complicated problems set by a palace building
label: Paragraph

text: where women played an important role; he quite lost sight of
label: Paragraph

text: the ladies. The part that women play in the development of
label: Paragraph

text: French architecture from this period onward is a very impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant one.
label: Paragraph

text: The elaborate routine of court ceremonies is another major
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning circumstance. These changes in French social
label: Paragraph

text: life dictated a more complicated arrangement of rooms in
label: Paragraph

text: great houses. A new delicacy and refinement appears in their
label: Paragraph

text: treatment. At the same time changes are made in the designs
label: Paragraph

text: of furniture, especially as concerns such pieces as are intended
label: Paragraph

text: for sitting and lying: these become better accommodated to
label: Paragraph

text: women, and to love-making.
label: Paragraph

text: At this period in France the general type of dwelling was being
label: Paragraph

text: transformed; the chateau was replacing the villa of Italian
label: Paragraph

text: style. The town mansions of the nobility and of high state
label: Paragraph

text: officials, buildings like the Hétel Lambert which Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Le Vau built at Paris in 1650, showed a highly developed
label: Paragraph

text: dwelling culture that had arisen out of the special requirements
label: Paragraph

text: of French life. But very soon the growth of this culture was to
label: Paragraph

text: be impeded. The importance of the great nobles, the wealthy
label: Paragraph

text: financiers, and the chief state functionaries alike was eclipsed
label: Paragraph

text: by the demands of an absolute king.
label: Paragraph

text: In keeping with this change, the royal chateau — placed out-
label: Paragraph

text: side the city — became both the social and the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: center. It dominated the town behind it and the natural ter-
label: Paragraph

text: rain that spread out before it. The idea of locating the chateau
label: Paragraph

text: midway between town and country had originated in Italy
label: Paragraph

text: considerably earlier. Michelangelo, for example, when build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the Palazzo Farnese in Rome, had conceived the fantastic
label: Paragraph

text: notion of throwing a bridge across the Tiber as a means of
label: Paragraph

text: prolonging the axis of the palace far beyond the other side of
label: Paragraph

text: the river.
label: Paragraph

text: It was not the French king, however, but Fouquet, the great-
label: Paragraph

text: est financier of his time, who was the first to carry this open
label: Paragraph

text: style of chateau construction to its logical conclusion, in the
label: Paragraph

text: chateau of Vaux-le-Vicomte. This chateau was built by the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Louis Le Vau just past the middle of the seventeenth
label: Caption

text: century, 1655-61 (fig. 24). It was comparatively modest in
label: Paragraph

text: size, but it faced an immense park, the work of André Le
label: Paragraph

text: Notre. The chateau is built on the principle of the French
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion. The steep roofs with their tall chimneys are reminis-
label: Paragraph

text: cent of Gothic tower-caps; they are in abrupt contrast with
label: Paragraph

text: the cupola and its lantern of the middle pavilion. We can well
label: Paragraph

text: imagine the kind of impression this mixture of building styles
label: Paragraph

text: must, have made on Lorenzo Bernini, who was in Paris at the
label: Paragraph

text: time the chateau was erected. Nevertheless, Vaux-le-Vicomte
label: Paragraph

text: was the first instance of a dwelling designed in close unity with
label: Paragraph

text: The chateau of Versailles symbolizes the supplanting of the
label: Paragraph

text: ecclesiastical authority of a pope by the secular absolutism of
label: Paragraph

text: aking. It took Louis XJV nearly half a century (1661 -1708)
label: Paragraph

text: to erect Versailles in all its magnilicence. He began the work
label: Paragraph

text: when he was twenty-two, firmly rejecting the suggesLions of his
label: Paragraph

text: minister Colbert, who advised him lo complete the residence
label: Paragraph

text: of his ancestors, the Louvre in Paris. Of another generation
label: Paragraph

text: than Colbert, Louis cared neither for the old palace nor for
label: Paragraph

text: his capital city of Paris. Bernini, then nearly seventy years
label: Paragraph

text: old, had been brought all the way from Rome to Paris and had
label: Paragraph

text: been presented by Colbert with a complete list of the require-
label: Paragraph

text: ‘ments for a royal residence. But all this was quile in vain;
label: Paragraph

text: Louis NIV had other ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: In particular, the notion of mastering nature, forcer la nature,
label: Paragraph

text: fascinated the King. Louis XIV detested the narrow streets
label: Paragraph

text: of Paris. A dislike of large cilics was, indeed, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics of baroque absolutism everywhere. ven when
label: Paragraph

text: new towns were founded in connection with the new palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: they failed to prosper. This was to prove true in the case of
label: Paragraph

text: Versailles, as well as in those of Mannheim and Karlsruhe.
label: Paragraph

text: Bul, in any event, Versailles and the idea of creating a new
label: Paragraph

text: mode of life that would be unrestricted by the confines of a
label: Paragraph

text: city preoccupied Louis intensely for more than thirty years —
label: Paragraph

text: this in spite of the fact that it was an unprecedented thing for
label: Paragraph

text: a ruling monarch to desert and neglect the capital of his
label: Paragraph

text: courlry,
label: Title

text: The Versailles of Louis XIII’s day had been a mere hunting-
label: Paragraph

text: seat, built on a low hill which was surrounded by woods. It
label: Paragraph

text: was at first merely enlarged. But these alterations — carried
label: Paragraph

text: through by the architect of Vanx-le-Vicomte, Louis Le Vau—
label: Paragraph

text: did not suffice; larger dimensions were necessary. During the
label: Paragraph

text: years 1668-74 a new conception took shape, a conception
label: Paragraph

text: gigantic in scale (fig. 25). The great U-shaped, central block
label: Caption

text: faces the park. Jules Hardouin-Mansard elongated the front
label: Caption

text: of the palace by building a long wing at right angles to each
label: Paragraph

text: end of the U. The left wing (1679-82) was built for the royal
label: Paragraph

text: princes; the right wing (begun in 1684) was built as an office
label: Paragraph

text: building for the various French ministries. (It was in 1683,
label: Paragraph

text: when he decided to house the administration of France in his
label: Paragraph

text: own palace, that Louis XIV proclaimed Versailles as_ his
label: Paragraph

text: official residence. The proclamation almost caused a revoll in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris.)
label: Paragraph

text: The two long wings combined with the U of the central block
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in an open style of construction that had been hitherto
label: Paragraph

text: unknown. The whole structure, complex and enormous,
label: Paragraph

text: served three functions: it housed the King, the royal family,
label: Paragraph

text: and the ministries of France. Building activity on these
label: Paragraph

text: immense residential quarters was carried on at its greatest
label: Paragraph

text: intensity in the years from 1668 to 1684; thirty thousand men
label: Paragraph

text: were employed on the work. The interval in question corre-
label: Paragraph

text: sponds exactly to the rise of the absolute monarchy. At the
label: Paragraph

text: same time, Roman baroque architecture underwent the last
label: Paragraph

text: phase of its development in the work of Borromini and
label: Paragraph

text: Guarini.
label: Paragraph

text: What is the significance of Versailles? What is the important
label: Paragraph

text: constituent fact it embodies? It is the close contact it effects
label: Paragraph

text: with nature. An immense complex of buildings, more than two
label: Paragraph

text: thousand fect long, has been directly confronted with nature;
label: Paragraph

text: the grounds are a real part of the structure itself, and form with
label: Paragraph

text: it a whole of great power and grandeur.
label: Paragraph

text: Lorenzo Bernini had not been permitted to carry out his
label: Paragraph

text: project for the Louvre; nevertheless, when Louis XIV began
label: Paragraph

text: the new enlargement of Versailles in 1668, Roman grandeur,
label: Paragraph

text: grandezza, scored a success. Straight lines and flat roofs
label: Paragraph

text: replaced the crabbed medieval silhouette. In the simplicity of
label: Paragraph

text: a long straight line, used without deviation, there lies a tre-
label: Paragraph

text: mendous courage and self-assertiveness. The whole edifice is
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural response to a new sociological demand: the
label: Paragraph

text: demand for a new setting for the personal, the ceremonial, and
label: Paragraph

text: the governmental life of an absolute king. The major functions
label: Paragraph

text: combined under its one roof have already been noted. Less
label: Paragraph

text: important ones were likewise provided for; the salons, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, for all their mythological names, were acLually in-
label: Paragraph

text: tended for gambling, dancing, and musical entertainments.
label: Paragraph

text: But the interesting thing is still the manner in which great
label: Paragraph

text: complex buildings for social, residential, and administrative
label: Paragraph

text: purposes have been welded together and closely juxtaposed
label: Paragraph

text: with nature (fig. 27). Versailles is important not because of
label: Paragraph

text: its royal splendor but because it clearly reveals the solution to
label: Paragraph

text: a problem of living. Nature had been mastered before by
label: Paragraph

text: man’s will, but never before had so large a community been
label: Paragraph

text: housed under one roof, in open country, away from any big
label: Paragraph

text: Early Skeleton Buildings
label: Title

text: The first building of true skeleton type was the chocolate works
label: Paragraph

text: constructed in 1871-72 by Jules Saulnier at Noisiel-sur-Marne,
label: Caption

text: near Paris (fig. 74). The factory resls on four piers set into the
label: Paragraph

text: bed of the Marne, whose current supplied the power for its
label: Paragraph

text: machinery. The building itself is erected upon four hollow
label: Paragraph

text: iron girders, each square in section. The building whose base
label: Paragraph

text: these girders constitute is the first lo employ the principles of
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton construction, the first, that is, in which an iron skele-
label: Paragraph

text: ton is made to carry the whole weight. This skeleton can be
label: Paragraph

text: seen on the surfaces of the walls; the latter, made of hollow
label: Paragraph

text: brick, function merely as filling. The diagonal iron stiffeners
label: Paragraph

text: show clearly that Saulnier derived a part of his imspiration
label: Paragraph

text: from methods used in wood construction.
label: Paragraph

text: All contemporary buildings intended to have any formal or
label: Paragraph

text: stately character had their walls overloaded with decoration,
label: Paragraph

text: The walls of this chocolate works are plane surfaces. As
label: Paragraph

text: Saulnier himself explains, the construction was responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: this: ** The system of construction used for the facades pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced a surface entirely plane from top lo bottom, with no
label: Paragraph

text: projections either horizontal or vertical.” * Huropean Laste
label: Paragraph

text: in the early seventies nevertheless required some concessions
label: Paragraph

text: on Saulnier’s part. Although he scrupulously preserved the
label: Paragraph

text: flat surfaces that followed from the logic of his method. the
label: Paragraph

text: brickwork defining them embodies a pattern in varicolored
label: Paragraph

text: tiles.
label: Paragraph

text: We can see in this building how the flat and unornamented
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces of present-day architecture appeared simultaneously
label: Paragraph

text: with the new structural means (fig. 75). Moreover, this took
label: Paragraph

text: place in spile of the fact that monumental archilecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: late nineleenth century was developing along entirely different
label: Paragraph

text: Market Halls
label: Title

text: One of the new problems that were arising first finds a solution
label: Paragraph

text: in the great public markets, three examples cf which will be
label: Paragraph

text: given. The earliest of such structures Lo require discussion
label: Paragraph

text: here was the market hall of the Madeleine, built in Paris in
label: Paragraph

text: 1824. (fig. 89). The grace of ils slender cast-iron columns is
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of Pompeian mural paintings. The lightness of
label: Paragraph

text: the construction is unbroken by any purely decorative addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions. This is one of the earliest examples of the attempts
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century engineers were making to develop methods
label: Paragraph

text: of construction which would combine elegance with economy
label: Paragraph

text: of material.
label: Paragraph

text: The market which was built in London in 1835 to replace the
label: Paragraph

text: old Hungerford Fish Market represents a somewhat greater
label: Paragraph

text: advance, so far as construction alone is concerned. A detailed
label: Paragraph

text: description of the new Hungerford Fish Market (fig. 90)
label: Caption

text: appeared in the Transactions of the Institute of British Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects in 1836.2 On sanitary grounds, the use of lumber in this
label: Paragraph

text: building had been forbidden. The cast-iron construction
label: Paragraph

text: dictated by this provision is particularly noteworthy for the
label: Paragraph

text: wide roof span of thirty-two feet, with its straight line. It has
label: Paragraph

text: all the elegance of a much later period. “ The chief particular-
label: Paragraph

text: ity in the construction,” according to the report of 1836, “is
label: Paragraph

text: the absence of any tie or lateral abutment.”’ Already we find
label: Paragraph

text: the planes of the roof given an inward slope, so that rain water
label: Paragraph

text: might be carried away through the central columns.
label: Paragraph

text: The Grandes Halles of Paris, begun in 1853, had both a more
label: Paragraph

text: interesling origin and a greater future influence than either of
label: Paragraph

text: the structures we have just discussed. This market, the first
label: Paragraph

text: designed to serve a population in the millions, was a part of
label: Paragraph

text: H aussmann’s great transformation of Paris. The Grandes
label: Paragraph

text: [alles consist of two groups of pavilions connected by covered
label: Paragraph

text: passageways. Their designer, Victor Baltard, is not by any
label: Paragraph

text: means to be regarded as one of the great architects. His
label: Paragraph

text: initial attempt —- a stone pavilion that was built in 1851 —
label: Paragraph

text: aroused a public disapproval so clamorous that Haussmann
label: Paragraph

text: then newly appointed prefect, ordered it pulled down.
label: Paragraph

text: It was only direct commands by Napoleon ITI and Haussmann
label: Paragraph

text: that induced the academic Baltard to turn to iron construction
label: Paragraph

text: in his second attempt (fig. 91). Napoleon III, greatly impressed
label: Paragraph

text: by the recently built Gare de l'Est, had decided that a similar
label: Paragraph

text: umbrella-like shelter was all that was required in the projected
label: Paragraph

text: market hall. “ Ce sont de vastes parapluies qu’il me faut, rien
label: Caption

text: de plus!’ And the prefect Haussmann thundered at Baltard
label: Paragraph

text: “Du fer! Du fer! Rien que du fer!” The final design that
label: Paragraph

text: Baltard produced under this pressure was a derivative patch-
label: Paragraph

text: work of other men’s plans; for all that, it had an important
label: Paragraph

text: influence on future work.
label: Paragraph

text: The new version, all iron and glass, once again amazed Na-
label: Paragraph

text: polcon IIT when Haussmann brought it to him — this time for
label: Paragraph

text: different reasons. “ Is it possible,’’ he asked, ‘“ that the same
label: Paragraph

text: architect designed two such contradictory buildings? ” Hauss-
label: Paragraph

text: mann replied, “ The architect is the same, but the prefect is
label: Paragraph

text: different.” |
label: Paragraph

text: The project actually realized in the Grandes Halles is less
label: Paragraph

text: interesting than two designs which were rejected. The first
label: Paragraph

text: was the work of Hector Horeau (1801-1872). Hector Horeau
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: fulfillment. His projects — all on a grand scale —- could not
label: Paragraph

text: be exeeuted. Mathematical theory had not yet progressed to
label: Paragraph

text: a point where the calculations required for such buildings could
label: Paragraph

text: be carried through; it was still impossible to build spans as

text: “Du fer! Du fer! Rien que du fer!” Haussmann insisted.
label: Paragraph

text: Flachat belonged to the most forceful generation of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century, that of 1830, which included De Lesseps, the
label: Paragraph

text: builder of the Suez Canal, Victor Hugo, the painter Eugéne
label: Paragraph

text: Delacroix, and Auguste Comte, the prophet of the scientific
label: Title

text: era. It was Flachat who, overcoming widespread resist-
label: Paragraph

text: ance, built the first French railroad in 1837. He designed
label: Paragraph

text: docks, warehouses, ports and canals, projected transatlantic
label: Title

text: steamship companies, and planned a tunnel through the
label: Paragraph

text: Alps.
label: Paragraph

text: That Flachat was a follower of Saint-Simon is by no means
label: Paragraph

text: irrelevant to this recital. The Saint-Simonists took it as
label: Paragraph

text: axiomatic that “ la Société toute entiére repose sur l’industrie,”
label: Paragraph

text: and were almost alone in foreseeing the scale and the extent of
label: Paragraph

text: the progress that industry was embarking upon. The Grandes
label: Paragraph

text: Halles (fig. 93), in its magnitude and social function, was a
label: Paragraph

text: typical part of that new age the Saint-Simonists felt them-
label: Paragraph

text: selves destined to call forth. In submitting a plan for it,
label: Paragraph

text: Flachat was animated by the same spirit that stood behind his
label: Paragraph

text: other more grandiose proposals.
label: Paragraph

text: The design itself, like Horeau’s, features a very wide span —
label: Paragraph

text: one of 260 feet. It could, nevertheless, have been executed with
label: Paragraph

text: the means available at the Lime. The Polonceau tie system is
label: Paragraph

text: employed, and, with its minimum of support and widely
label: Paragraph

text: spread horizontal lines, the plan achieves a most pleasing and
label: Paragraph

text: functional solution to the problem posed.

text: Depariment Slores
label: Title

text: The department store is a product of the industrial age; it
label: Paragraph

text: results from the development of mass production and from the
label: Paragraph

text: loss of direct contact between producer and consumer that was
label: Paragraph

text: one of its consequences. The department store has no equally
label: Paragraph

text: large forerunner in the past. In this respect it is like the market
label: Paragraph

text: halls, railway stations, and exhibition buildings of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century, and the object it serves is the same: the rapid
label: Paragraph

text: handling of business activities involving huge crowds of
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrians. Like these other buildings, the department
label: Paragraph

text: store arises out of the growth in the population of cities,
label: Paragraph

text: the heightened tempo of living, and the demand for cheaper
label: Paragraph

text: goods.

text: The name “ store ” rather than “shop ” points to the condi-

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: met with the new means open to the builder.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: kind was opened. We can only outline the general types out of
label: Paragraph

text: which this important institution of our economic life has
label: Paragraph

text: THE GREAT EXHIBITIONS
label: Title

text: In the second half of the nineteenth century, with industry
label: Paragraph

text: undergoing its greatest expansion, industrial exhibitions
label: Paragraph

text: afforded truly creative architecture its best opportunities.
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Toward the end of the century, when industry had come to be
label: Paragraph

text: taken as a matter of course and was no jonger looked upon
label: Paragraph

text: as new and marvelous, they lost their creative force. New
label: Paragraph

text: problems had emerged in the meantime which demanded new
label: Paragraph

text: solutions.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibitions were born almost simultaneously with modern
label: Paragraph

text: industry; they appeared at the time when the shift from hand-
label: Paragraph

text: work to machine production made itself obvious. Throughout
label: Paragraph

text: that period people in many countries were working feverishly
label: Paragraph

text: to invent new machines and new processes. The chief purpose
label: Paragraph

text: of the early exhibitions was to bring together the resulls of this
label: Paragraph

text: work, to display the new discoveries side by side, and thus to
label: Paragraph

text: facilitate their comparison and adoption. The development of
label: Paragraph

text: industry in all its branches was accelerated by these exhibitions,
label: Paragraph

text: in which every sphere of human activity was represented: the
label: Paragraph

text: implements, methods, and products of mines, mills, machine
label: Title

text: shops, and farms were on display, together wilh work in the
label: Paragraph

text: fine and the applied arts.
label: Paragraph

text: The industrial exhibition embodied a synthesis of the as yet
label: Paragraph

text: unformulated aims of the nineteenth century. h. foretold the
label: Paragraph

text: transformation that was to be effected in man as well as in
label: Paragraph

text: industry, in human feelings as well as in human surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibitions were a part of the march of industry and were
label: Paragraph

text: pound up in its destiny.
label: Paragraph

text: The history of the exhibition is divided into two periods.
label: Paragraph

text: The earlier of these periods opens and closes in Paris; it begins
label: Paragraph

text: with the first industrial exhibition ever held that of 1798 —
label: Paragraph

text: and ends with the Paris exhibition of 1849. The exhibitions of
label: Paragraph

text: this initial period were made possible by the collapse of the
label: Paragraph

text: guilds in 1791, and were all purely national in character.
label: Paragraph

text: The premiére exposition des produils de Uindusirie frangaise
label: Caption

text: was opened on the Champ-de-Mars in Paris in September
label: Paragraph

text: 1798 (fig. 101). It inaugurated an exhibition movement which
label: Paragraph

text: was to lead to some of the outstanding achievements of the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century. The start made at Paris in 1798 was a very
label: Paragraph

text: modest one. There were some luxury articles displayed, but
label: Paragraph

text: the precedent for nearly all future exhibitions was set by the
label: Paragraph

text: central position given to articles of daily use: watches, wall
label: Paragraph

text: paper, cloth, and cotton yarn — yarn which “ was carded and
label: Paragraph

text: spun by means of machinery,” as the catalogue was careful to
label: Paragraph

text: state.
label: Paragraph

text: There were only a hundred and ten exhibitors at this first
label: Paragraph

text: exposition, but this does not detract from its imporLlance. It
label: Paragraph

text: was primarily intended as a sort of people’s festival, in celebra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the freedom from guild restrictions that the Revolution
label: Title

text: had brought. This festive motive accounted for its location
label: Paragraph

text: in the Champ-de-Mars, the scene of all national celebrations
label: Paragraph

text: since the fall of the monarchy. It was the proclamation de
label: Paragraph

text: la liberlé da travail in 1791 that first gave every citizen the
label: Paragraph

text: right to follow whatever trade he desired. What was more
label: Paragraph

text: important, this proclamation, in according a new liberty to
label: Paragraph

text: production, gave official encouragement to a progress of in-
label: Paragraph

text: dustry and invention from which everyone expected great
label: Paragraph

text: things. “Ces arts n’avaient pas pu encore se developper A
label: Paragraph

text: cause des entraves sans nombre. Mais la liberté les vengerait.
label: Caption

text: ... Sous Pégide de la liberté, les arts utiles étaient appelés a
label: Caption

text: un brilliant avenir.”’
label: Paragraph

text: The second period occupies the latter half of the nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century and owes its force to the principle of free trade. In
label: Paragraph

text: this period the exhibition takes on a new character: it becomes
label: Paragraph

text: international in its scope. The national exhibitions of industry
label: Paragraph

text: during the first half of the century had followed upon the
label: Paragraph

text: abolition of the legal obligation to belong to a guild. Some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing else was demanded for an international exhibition; there
label: Paragraph

text: was no reason to bring together products from all over the
label: Paragraph

text: world unless there existed at the same time the possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: selling to the whole world. An international exhibition could
label: Paragraph

text: have value only in a world where trade restrictions of all kinds
label: Paragraph

text: had been reduced to a minimum. These great exhibitions were
label: Paragraph

text: the product of the liberal conception of economy: free trade,
label: Paragraph

text: free communication, and improvement im production and
label: Title

text: performance through free competition.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibitions also fostered a spirit of rivalry, a desire to equal
label: Paragraph

text: or improve upon the last exhibition. Thus risks were taken in
label: Paragraph

text: many departments, not least of all in architecture. Such a
label: Paragraph

text: spirit of rivalry, together with the efficiency it promoted, is
label: Paragraph

text: visible in the Crystal Palace world exhibition of 1851.
label: Caption

text: The history of exhibitions during the latter half of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century constitutes at the same time a history of iron
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Exhibition buildings were planned for rapid
label: Paragraph

text: erection and dismantling: both were facilitated by the use of
label: Paragraph

text: iron. Again, iron parts for such buildings could be fabricated
label: Paragraph

text: in widely separated workshops. Finally, iron was everywhere
label: Paragraph

text: regarded at this date as ihe medium of expression most truly
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate to the period. But exhibition buildings did not
label: Paragraph

text: simply call for the use of iron; the fact that they appeared at
label: Paragraph

text: short intervals and were meant to be only temporary encour-
label: Paragraph

text: aged the experimental employment of iron in their construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition became the trial ground for new methods. In
label: Paragraph

text: all the great international exhibitions — from the first at
label: Paragraph

text: Crystal Palace, London, in 1851 to the last at the end of the
label: Caption

text: century — constructors attempted tasks that had never been
label: Paragraph

text: faced before. When their experiments succeeded in this special
label: Paragraph

text: Geld they became a part of standard building practice. Tt
label: Paragraph

text: was in this way that the Eiffel Tower came. to be erected in
label: Paragraph

text: 1889, despite the most doleful prophecies of disaster.
label: Paragraph

text: The history of the exhibition shows not only the development:
label: Paragraph

text: in iron construction during the period but also impo ta t
label: Paragraph

text: changes in habits of aesthetic response. The new street al
label: Caption

text: treatments of load and support demanded new aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: reactions. In the past people had grown to expect the basi "
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: visible ata glance, to lie open to inspection. But with the i tt :
label: Paragraph

text: d uction of new methods of iron construction it became m rand
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The very complete surveys published by the countries where
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibitions were held show a contemporary realization of
label: Paragraph

text: their unique importance. They were edited with great care;
label: Paragraph

text: later generations will find them the most satisfactory sources
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: initiative. Henry Cole was responsible for the first of these
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Exhibitions grew out of the old fairs, familiar to every century.
label: Paragraph

text: The first French exhibition in 1798 was essentially a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: people's festival, and all later exhibitions retained this festival
label: Paragraph

text: motif.
label: Paragraph

text: The nineteenth century marks the point when leisure vanished
label: Paragraph

text: from daily life. The ability to develop an original form for
label: Paragraph

text: festivals vanished with it. During the second half of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century the exbibitions remained the great festivals in
label: Paragraph

text: the life of nations. Warehouses, department stores, and office
label: Caption

text: buildings remained closely bound up with immediate practical
label: Paragraph

text: needs. The exhibitions had their practical function to fulfill
label: Paragraph

text: also, but they operated in an atmosphere far removed from
label: Paragraph

text: the rush of everyday life and were able to sustain a festive
label: Paragraph

text: character. There was always a sharp contrast between their
label: Paragraph

text: festive and their practical or official aspects. The sureness
label: Paragraph

text: which appears in the construction of their great halls is not
label: Paragraph

text: carried over into the social arrangements in the interiors of
label: Paragraph

text: the halls, for example. But, even so, they represent the
label: Paragraph

text: closest approach of the period to an original form of group
label: Paragraph

text: celebration.
label: Paragraph

text: Even in the nineteenth century, when architecture was rooted
label: Paragraph

text: in the background of industrial development, it was in these
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of a certain festive intent that the great solutions of
label: Paragraph

text: the period to the vaulting problem were made.
label: Paragraph

text: From the beginning of architecture the vaulting problem has
label: Paragraph

text: always brought forth the highest architectural expressions of
label: Paragraph

text: every epoch. Thus the barrel vault painted by Masaccio dur-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the early Renaissance was developed into a ceremonious
label: Paragraph

text: expression of the full Renaissance and early baroque world
label: Title

text: In the late baroque, changes in vaulting once again accom-
label: Paragraph

text: panied changes in the outlook of the age.
label: Paragraph

text: Solutions to the vaulting problem played the same important
label: Paragraph

text: role in the nineteenth century. The haut godi of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth-century style in architecture requires — as we have
label: Paragraph

text: already noted more than once — more careful study than it has
label: Paragraph

text: yet been given. But, whatever results such a study may lead
label: Paragraph

text: io, the constituent facts of architectural development will be
label: Paragraph

text: found to be those original solutions of the vaulting problem
label: Paragraph

text: which first took shape in the large halls of great exhibitions.
label: Paragraph

text: Objections to this view could readily be advanced. It might
label: Paragraph

text: be said that these exhibition buildings represented nothing but
label: Paragraph

text: the answers to very sober practical needs, while the vaulting
label: Paragraph

text: problem had possessed an almost metaphysical significance in
label: Paragraph

text: earlier periods. . ° :
label: Paragraph

text: These objections cannot be ignored. Furthermore, it is obvious
label: Paragraph

text: that such exhibition buildings were out of direct contact with
label: Paragraph

text: human needs. But in a certain sense this remark applies to
label: Paragraph

text: the period as a whole. Their indifference to human needs
label: Paragraph

text: makes these constructions a true — if harsh -—— expression of
label: Paragraph

text: the times. Nevertheless we may succeed in showing that be-
label: Paragraph

text: hind this indifference a new feeling lies hidden.

text: The Crystal Palace (fig. 102) had the impact of a fairy story on
label: Paragraph

text: all those who saw it opened in London in 1851. Industry, after
label: Paragraph

text: all the blight and disorder it had brought about, now displayed
label: Paragraph

text: another and a gentler side, aroused feclings that seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: belong only to the world of dreams.
label: Paragraph

text: The Crystal Palace housed an exhibition that was the first of
label: Paragraph

text: its kind, one that reflected the courage and enterprise of the
label: Paragraph

text: early Victorian period. The Prince Consort, Albert, and Sir
label: Paragraph

text: Henry Cole @ were its leading spirits, and it was the former
label: Paragraph

text: who gave it a central theme. Cole relates a conversation he
label: Paragraph

text: had with Prince Albert at Buckingham Palace on June 29,
label: Paragraph

text: 1849: “ I asked the Prince if he had considered [whether] the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition should be a national or an international exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: The French had discussed whether their own exhibition should
label: Paragraph

text: be international, and had preferred that it should be national
label: Paragraph

text: only. The Prince reflected for a minute and then said, ‘It
label: Paragraph

text: must embrace foreign productions ’ — to use his words — and
label: Paragraph

text: added emphatically, ‘ International, certainly. ... Where do
label: Paragraph

text: you think it should be?’ I answered, ‘ In Hyde Park.’”” The
label: Paragraph

text: prince’s decision was by no means a casual reply. In 1850 he
label: Paragraph

text: declared: “ None will doubt that we are living ina most remark-
label: Paragraph

text: able period of transition, laboring forcefully toward that great
label: Paragraph

text: aim indicated everywhere by history: the union of the human
label: Title

text: race... Gentlemen, the exhibition of 1851 shall give a vivid
label: Paragraph

text: picture of the stage at which-industry has arrived in the solution
label: Paragraph

text: of that great task.””

text: PART IV
label: Title

text: THE DEMAND FOR MORALITY
label: Title

text: IN ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: THE NINETIES: PRECURSORS OF CONTEMPORARY
label: Title

text: ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: ‘There are whole decades in the second half of the nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century in which no architectural work of any significance is
label: Paragraph

text: encountered. Eclecticism smothered all creative energy. Here
label: Paragraph

text: and there — especially as the century wore on -—~ voices were
label: Paragraph

text: raised in protest, but they could do nothing to alter conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: It was just at this time that an unprecedented wave of building
label: Paragraph

text: activity swept over Europe. Its cities took on the shapes from
label: Paragraph

text: which we still suffer today.
label: Paragraph

text: The painter was able to withdraw from this overpowering
label: Paragraph

text: environment. The men who did the important work at this
label: Paragraph

text: period gave up all prospects of fame and an audience and
label: Paragraph

text: practiced their art in seclusion. Cézanne and Van Gogh, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, buried themselves in the solitude of Provence. The
label: Paragraph

text: architect had no such course open to him; not a single one
label: Paragraph

text: managed to escape from the atmosphere of eclecticism.
label: Paragraph

text: Dissatisfaction with this almost universal state of affairs
label: Title

text: reached its peak around 1890. Toward the end of the century
label: Paragraph

text: H. P. Berlage was to produce a building which. would serve to
label: Paragraph

text: purify architecture all over Europe, his Amsterdam Stock
label: Paragraph

text: Exchange. In the nineties he was already denouncing the
label: Paragraph

text: prevailing architecture as “ Scheinarchitektur, d-h. Imitation,
label: Paragraph

text: ah. Liige ” (‘‘ Sham architecture; i.e., imitation; iLe., lying”).
label: Paragraph

text: “ Our parents and grandparents as well as ourselves,” Berlage
label: Paragraph

text: wrote, ‘ have lived and still live in surroundings more hideous
label: Paragraph

text: than any known before. . . . Lying is the rule, truth is the
label: Paragraph

text: exception.”
label: Paragraph

text: The smoldering hatred of eclecticism came to a head in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: with startling suddenness. In the same way, a fish net can be
label: Paragraph

text: hauled for a long time quite uneventfully and then, in a single
label: Paragraph

text: moment, the whole catch shows up all bunched together. This
label: Paragraph

text: moment in the history of architecture did not arrive by acci-
label: Paragraph

text: dent: industry had at length reached its full development and
label: Paragraph

text: the time was ripe for great changes. In the earlier part of the
label: Paragraph

text: century decades go by with nothing achieved in architecture;
label: Paragraph

text: toward the close of the century almost every year has impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tance. Ambition revives and brings with it courage and
label: Paragraph

text: strength to oppose those forces which had kept life from finding
label: Paragraph

text: its true forms. Developments come in one surge afler another.
label: Paragraph

text: The diversity of movements with their variety of experimental
label: Paragraph

text: gropings indicates the vilality of the period. Individual fail-
label: Paragraph

text: ures and the mixture of transitory with constituent facts are of
label: Paragraph

text: little imporlance. These are traits of every transitional period.
label: Paragraph

text: Much of what was attempted between 1890 and 1930 remained
label: Paragraph

text: fragmentary and incomplete. This period, however, found the
label: Paragraph

text: courage to undertake the building up of a tradition of its own.
label: Paragraph

text: What Were the Sources of this Movement?
label: Paragraph

text: According to the easy explanation that was advanced later, the
label: Paragraph

text: movement developed as the application of two principles: the
label: Paragraph

text: abandonment of historical styles, and — consequent upon this
label: Paragraph

text: -— the use of “ fitness for purpose”’ as a criterion. The ex-
label: Paragraph

text: planation is correct, inasmuch as both these factors were in-
label: Paragraph

text: volved, but it does not go far enough. The movement took its
label: Paragraph

text: strength from the moral demands which were its real source.
label: Paragraph

text: The cry went up, “ Away with this infected atmosphere! ”
label: Paragraph

text: The young painter Henri van de Velde was among those who
label: Paragraph

text: attacked the “ infected atmosphere ”’ most vigorously. In the
label: Paragraph

text: late nineties he took the lead in the fight for art moderne. He
label: Paragraph

text: campaigned for it first in his native Belgium, next in France,
label: Paragraph

text: and then in a country which, at the time, lay wide open to any
label: Paragraph

text: new movement — Germany. He has given the reasons why
label: Paragraph

text: his development took the direction it did in his writings, where
label: Paragraph

text: he preaches, explains, and defends his doctrines. But it may
label: Paragraph

text: be that the moral impetus behind the art moderne movement
label: Paragraph

text: appears more directly in some remarks which he made only a
label: Paragraph

text: short while ago. :
label: Paragraph

text: I met van de Velde in Brussels during the summer of 1938.
label: Paragraph

text: A great leader during the nineties, he still remains extremely
label: Paragraph

text: active; he had, in fact, just returned from laying the corner-
label: Paragraph

text: stone of the Belgian Pavilion at the New York World’s Fair.
label: Caption

text: Knowing that he had begun his career as a painter, I asked
label: Paragraph

text: him how he had come to turn to architecture. He answered by
label: Paragraph

text: describing the situation that prevailed around 1890: “ The
label: Paragraph

text: real forms of things were covered over. In this period the
label: Paragraph

text: revolt against the falsification of forms and against the past
label: Title

text: was a moral revolt.” *
label: Paragraph

text: He went on to tell how, shortly before 1890, a nervous break-
label: Paragraph

text: down had left him incapable of work. At this point he met a
label: Paragraph

text: woman who gave him renewed courage to face life. Soon after,
label: Paragraph

text: he wished to marry and establish his own household. “I told
label: Paragraph

text: myself — this was in 1892 — that I would never allow my
label: Paragraph

text: wife and family to find themselves in ‘immoral’ surround-
label: Paragraph

text: ings.” ? But at that date everything that one could buy on the
label: Paragraph

text: open market was smothered under the mensonge des formes
label: Paragraph

text: which van de Velde hated. He had to design for himself every-
label: Paragraph

text: thing in his house, from cutlery to doorknobs. Then — since
label: Paragraph

text: these articles demanded a setting which would * ward off ugli-
label: Paragraph

text: ness” — he was led to build his first house. “You asked me
label: Paragraph

text: how I became an architect. Well, this house pushed me into
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.”
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In 1881 Maus, Picard, and some others founded the weekly
label: Paragraph

text: periodical, L’Art moderne. Each number contained only a few
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: “ Art is for us the contrary of every recipe and formula. Art
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In Brussels between 1884 and 1894 the works of great con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary painters and sculptors found display. In England
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: arts was made. It was at this time that the work of Morris
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: was made to reform public taste in the field of household
label: Paragraph

text: furnishings. Meanwhile a younger generation of artists had
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: further by this younger generation.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tries Association. The Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The revolutionary aspect of Horta’s work consists in this: he
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Dutch painting and architecture in the nineteenth century
label: Title

text: exhibited considerable moderation. The cities of Holland suc-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tinental cities experienced. The Rijks Museum and Cuyper’s
label: Paragraph

text: railway station are examples of the mild eclecticism that
label: Paragraph

text: governed large buildings in Amsterdam.
label: Paragraph

text: On the other hand, Holland failed to take effective part in the
label: Paragraph

text: developments going on (under French leadership) in painting
label: Paragraph

text: and construction, or in the arts and crafts movement which
label: Paragraph

text: grew up in England. The Dutch stood aside from this activity:
label: Paragraph

text: they never quite lost sight of the great tradition they had to
label: Paragraph

text: preserve. And the seventeenth- and eighteenth-century man-
label: Paragraph

text: sions that stood alongside their canals served as guiet and con-

text: In the year 1894 Otto Wagner (1841-1918) was made professor
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The arl nouveau, in architecture at least, had its roots in the
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of iron construction. At the beginning of the century,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: peared a new pbuilding material which achieved a surprisingly
label: Paragraph

text: rapid influence upon architecture: ferroconcrete. It was at
label: Paragraph

text: this time that architecture tore itself loose from the prejudices
label: Paragraph

text: which had held it back for so long, and absorbed the new
label: Paragraph

text: methods that had grown out of the period itself. It was
label: Paragraph

text: this which promoted the use of ferroconcrete. Hardly had
label: Paragraph

text: it been developed to the point where mills, silos, and
label: Paragraph

text: reservoirs could be made from it than it was employed
label: Paragraph

text: for more purely architectural purposes. Between 1910
label: Paragraph

text: and 1920 it became almost the trademark of the new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Although it was very late in reaching maturity, this material
label: Paragraph

text: with its complicated composition has a past that goes very far
label: Paragraph

text: back. There is no need to retrace its technical development,
label: Paragraph

text: since there are many sources of information on the subject.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: architecture.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: A.G. Perrel®
label: Paragraph

text: Auguste Perret (born in 1873) remained an archilecte-ingénieur
label: Paragraph

text: throughout his career. Perret came from Burgundy, from a
label: Paragraph

text: town near the great monastery of Cluny. It was the Cluniac
label: Paragraph

text: monks who initiated the great reform and purification of church
label: Title

text: architecture carried out during the twelfth century.
label: Paragraph

text: Perret built his 25 bis Rue Franklin apartments in Paris in
label: Paragraph

text: 1903 (fig. 144), ten years after Horta’s Rue de Turin house.
label: Caption

text: This apartment house by no means embodies the pure forms of
label: Paragraph

text: the Chicago office buildings, and it fails to match the strength
label: Paragraph

text: of Frank Lloyd Wright’s work of the same period. The familiar
label: Paragraph

text: European restlessness is still present to a considerable degree.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, it represents the first employment of ferro-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete as a medium for architectonic expression, and many
label: Paragraph

text: of its features were Lo prove seeds for future developments.
label: Paragraph

text: The ferroconcrete skeleton is used without disguise; it stands
label: Paragraph

text: out plainly as one of the constituent elements of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Earlier buildings in concrete — Hennebique’s Rue Danton
label: Caption

text: apartments, for example — made no architectonic use of the
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton. The facade as a simple support for ornament has
label: Paragraph

text: been almost abandoned. A series of delicate progressions and
label: Paragraph

text: recessions removes from it all associations with weight. This
label: Paragraph

text: effect of lightness is reinforced by the way in which the seven
label: Paragraph

text: upper stories are cantilevered out over the street. And the
label: Paragraph

text: street floor (which at one time held Perret’s office) has been
label: Paragraph

text: almost dissolved into pure glass, broken only by a few narrow

text: character of the facade.
label: Paragraph

text: There are other fine works of Perret’s which, unfortunately, we

text: rary church buildings; his private houses; and his latest works.
label: Paragraph

text: Auguste Perret, with his sense for construction, gave Le Cor-
label: Paragraph

text: busier a decisive impetus toward his own work.
label: Paragraph

text: And the next generation of architects as a whole carried Per-
label: Paragraph

text: ret’s results still further. Per ret’sbuildings follow the best
label: Paragraph

text: ninetcenth-century French tradition in construction. Like
label: Paragraph

text: the earlier archilectes-ingénieurs, he drew his inspiration from
label: Paragraph

text: his materials. Perret did for ferroconcrete what Henri La-
label: Paragraph

text: brouste had done for iron.
label: Paragraph

text: Like Tony Garnier, Perret preserved some connections wilh
label: Paragraph

text: the classic past. But classical canons remained alive and flex-
label: Paragraph

text: ible for the best French architects, just as they had for the
label: Paragraph

text: French masters of baroque days—for Racine, Molitre,
label: Caption

text: and Descartes. Perhaps later on we shall come to see that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the men who came after Perret; that they too reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: classic urge toward balance, symmetry, and repose.

text: Tony Garnier
label: Title

text: The archilecte-constructeur Auguste Perret was the first to find
label: Paragraph

text: new architectonic means in the unexplored potentialities of
label: Paragraph

text: ferroconcrete. This material was, indeed, peculiarly attractive
label: Paragraph

text: to French builders. Conerete accorded perfectly with their
label: Paragraph

text: traditional penchant for daring and extensively hollowed out
label: Paragraph

text: structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Tony Garnier (born in 1869) made reinforced concrete the
label: Paragraph

text: basis of all his work. In his “ Cité Industrielle ” (1901-04) this
label: Paragraph

text: new material was used to organize a whole town along original
label: Paragraph

text: and strikingly farsighted lines. This is a scheme which we
label: Paragraph

text: shall discuss in some detail later on.** The Cité Industrielle,
label: Paragraph

text: planned when Garnier was only thirty, really laid down the
label: Paragraph

text: outlines for his whole future output. The “ grands travaux

text: We are approaching the moment when European architecture
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT
label: Title

text: The colonial and the republican periods were of great. impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tance to American development; they provided a solid foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dation for future advance. But the period between 1850 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1890 is more important for American influence on the outside
label: Paragraph

text: world. The preparations which made that influence possible
label: Paragraph

text: were completed during these decades. The years between 1850
label: Paragraph

text: and 1890 produced not only the great surge toward the un-
label: Paragraph

text: settled lands in the West but also strong manifestations of a
label: Paragraph

text: new and specifically American spirit. This period has partlicu-
label: Paragraph

text: lar significance to foreign eyes. The new forms which grew up
label: Paragraph

text: in it had their roots in an organization of labor altogether dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferent from that which prevails in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: The illustrative material published here was often unearthed
label: Paragraph

text: with difficulty. Documents from this period are not readily
label: Paragraph

text: accessible, just because there is so little interest in it and so
label: Paragraph

text: little understanding of its importance. Material showing the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the life of the period and the daily habits re-
label: Paragraph

text: flected in it is very difficult to find. What is of more impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tance, there is the constant danger that it will be lost forever.
label: Paragraph

text: Manufacturers simply laugh when asked for specimens of their
label: Paragraph

text: early productions and for old catalogues. There is no time for
label: Paragraph

text: and — above all — no interest in the sources of the tradition
label: Paragraph

text: which governs the life of the man of today. In the future, his-
label: Paragraph

text: torians who examine this period will certainly be more inter-
label: Paragraph

text: ested in uncovering the roots of the great anonymous produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of industry than they will be in the monumental or
label: Paragraph

text: official architecture of the time. But what institute tries, out

text: documents dealing with the anonymous beginnings of our

text: Until the seventies the balloon frame was called simply
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The balloon-frame building with its skeleton of thin machine-
label: Paragraph

text: cut studs and its covering of clapboards grew out of the seven-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth-century farmhouses of the early settlers. Snow was
label: Paragraph

text: familiar with such houses in his home state of New Hampshire
label: Paragraph

text: and his wife’s home, Connecticut, where they were especially
label: Paragraph

text: common. In these houses comparatively thin and narrow studs
label: Paragraph

text: were used as intermediary framing, with the whole construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion tied together by the clapboard covering.”
label: Paragraph

text: George Snow started with these traditional methods, changing
label: Paragraph

text: and adapting them to meet the new possibilities of production
label: Paragraph

text: in a way which was as simple as it was ingenious.
label: Paragraph

text: The balloon frame has kept its vitality for a whole century and
label: Paragraph

text: is still used extensively. This simple and efficient construction
label: Paragraph

text: is thoroughly adapted to the requirements of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architects. Many of Richard J. Neutra’s houses in Texas and
label: Paragraph

text: southern California reveal the elegance and lightness which are
label: Paragraph

text: innate gualities of the balloon-frame skeleton (fig. 159).
