text: of styles, for styles are those special aspects of periods which
label: Paragraph

text: mark them off one from the other.
label: Paragraph

text: Historical styles are particularly uninformative with regard to
label: Paragraph

text: what was actually going on in America. They arrived here
label: Paragraph

text: fully grown and give little insight into the constituent facts of
label: Paragraph

text: the native American development.
label: Paragraph

text: During the eighties European architecture lost more and more
label: Paragraph

text: of its dignity. The closer it clung to historical forms in the
label: Paragraph

text: search for security the more insecure it really became. In
label: Paragraph

text: barely fifty years the whole architectural inheritance of the
label: Paragraph

text: eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries was lost in a weller
label: Paragraph

text: of transitory detail. The inner unrest and uncertainty of the
label: Paragraph

text: period appears time and again in unbalanced treatments of the
label: Paragraph

text: wall and of the ground plan. The whole organism of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture was riddled by a fatal disease.
label: Paragraph

text: American independence of Europe showed itself in the develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of new and logical forms for tools and furniture, and in
label: Paragraph

text: the informal and flexible ground plan of the American house.
label: Paragraph

text: In the same way the wall maintained its unity and balance in
label: Paragraph

text: America throughout this whole period of European uncer-
label: Paragraph

text: tainty and confusion. America produced its share of grotesque
label: Paragraph

text: work during these years, but —in contrast to Europe —
label: Paragraph

text: attention never entirely strayed from the basic elements of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. These elements always remained dominant in
label: Paragraph

text: American work, taken as a whole. It may be that this is why
label: Paragraph

text: new architectural solutions were reached in America earlier
label: Paragraph

text: than they were abroad.
label: Paragraph

text: The plane surface — the flat wall of wood, brick, or stone —
label: Paragraph

text: bas always been a basic element in American architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In part this has been duc to the simplicity which a scarcity of
label: Paragraph

text: skilled labor enforced; in part it directly continues late eight-
label: Paragraph

text: eenth-century tendencies. The Georgian manner of treating
label: Paragraph

text: the brick wall has been carried over into the nineteenth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury; wooden houses have kept to traditions established by the
label: Paragraph

text: first settlers.
label: Paragraph

text: The brick wall, to be cheap, must be kept flat and simple.
label: Paragraph

text: All openings are cut very cleanly into the flat surtace of the
label: Paragraph

text: wall.

label: Paragraph

text: Such undisguised brick walls (fig. 160) are familiar features of
label: Paragraph

text: the American scene; they appear in New England mansions
label: Paragraph

text: of the late eighteenth century, in small anonymous buildings
label: Paragraph

text: on the main streets of all the cities, and in the big factories of
label: Paragraph

text: the Civil War period. The plain brick wall was firmly estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished as a basic element in architecture when men like Henry
label: Paragraph

text: Hobson Richardson began their work in the seventies. Rich-
label: Paragraph

text: ardson’s Sever Hall was built in 1878. We found a European
label: Paragraph

text: example of such scrupulously level surfaces in Berlage’s
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam Stock Exchange. But the Stock Exchange was
label: Paragraph

text: built two decades later; flat brick surfaces, such as Richardson
label: Paragraph

text: used, were almost unknown in the Europe of the seventies.
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright, too, was able to use the brick wall, taken
label: Paragraph

text: as a simple surface, from the very start. Unlike van de Velde
label: Paragraph

text: and Horta, there was no need for him to begin by crusading
label: Paragraph

text: against the mutilation and overcrowding of the wall, or to invent
label: Paragraph

text: an art nouveau to compete with established modes of ornamenta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. He was able to begin his work on a much higher level.
label: Paragraph

text: 161. Longfellow House, Cambridge, Mass., 1759. Clapboard wall of the sort which has
label: Caption

text: been used continuously in America for three centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: The wooden wall has been governed by eighteenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: American traditions to an even greater extent than the brick.
label: Paragraph

text: The simple clapboard wall ( fig. 161) has remained a constituent
label: Paragraph

text: element for three centuries, without any interruption, from the
label: Paragraph

text: time of the first colonists to the present. Clapboards had been
label: Paragraph

text: used in England, but only for unpretentious farmhouses. In
label: Paragraph

text: America they dominated the whole field of wooden building.
label: Paragraph

text: We find them everywhere, from the rudest huts to the finest
label: Paragraph

text: mansions, churches, and town halls. Such a widespread and
label: Paragraph

text: enduring authority for one type of wall treatment covering a
label: Paragraph

text: period of three hundred years is entirely unknown on the
label: Paragraph

text: other side of the Atlantic.
label: Paragraph

text: The use of clapboards automatically tends toward balanced
label: Paragraph

text: and simple treatments of the wall. They are ill suited to breaks
label: Paragraph

text: or interruptions in its flat expanse, and they discourage the use
label: Paragraph

text: of applied ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: Stone walls were treated with the same simplicity in states
label: Paragraph

text: where stone was used as a building material. Excellent work-
label: Paragraph

text: The Flexible and Informal Ground Plan
label: Title

text: American architecture has been marked by one tendency since
label: Paragraph

text: the arrival of the earliest settlers: the American house is given
label: Paragraph

text: a ground plan which can be enlarged whenever new social and
label: Paragraph

text: economic conditions make it desirable. This contrasts very
label: Paragraph

text: sharply with European procedure. In Europe a farmhouse is
label: Paragraph

text: planned as a solid, cubical unit from the very beginning.
label: Paragraph

text: Sometimes the interior is left unfinished, to be fitted up by
label: Paragraph

text: later generations when they come to need larger living quarters.
label: Paragraph

text: The American practice of adding new units to the original one
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen in those New England houses which survive from
label: Paragraph

text: the seventeenth century.*’ All these heavily timbered houses
label: Paragraph

text: began as one and a half or (at most) two-story structures, with
label: Paragraph

text: a single room on the ground floor. The next generation, with
label: Paragraph

text: improving circumstances, enlarged this ancestral nucleus both
label: Paragraph

text: horizontally and vertically. A new roof was spread over all
label: Paragraph

text: these additions, quite asymmetrically. But the important
label: Paragraph

text: thing was the addition of wings, which was very general.
label: Paragraph

text: The L-shaped ground plan, the beginning of the flexible and
label: Paragraph

text: informal layout, developed from this sort of planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Houses were not invariably enlarged. Sometimes — as in the
label: Paragraph

text: William Pepperell house at Kittery, Maine — they proved too
label: Paragraph

text: big for a later generation and were cut down. ‘ This family
label: Paragraph

text: mansion was then much more imposing than at present, being
label: Paragraph

text: 10 feet longer at cach end and surrounded by a beautiful park.
label: Paragraph

text: It was reduced after the American Revolution when the estate
label: Paragraph

text: was confiscated in 1779.” %

text: The interior of the typical American house is subdivided ag
label: Paragraph

text: little as possible. This urge to unite the various rooms and to
label: Paragraph

text: open the interior is occasionally reflected in the use of different
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: nineties.
label: Paragraph

text: Ninetcenth-century Americans who could afford to be stylish
label: Paragraph

text: had houses whose exterior forms reflected the styles in favor at
label: Paragraph

text: the time — romantic, Victorian, French Renaissance, Roman-
label: Paragraph

text: esque, or classical. The ground plan, however, generally
label: Paragraph

text: retained its soundness. The flexible and informal ground plan
label: Paragraph

text: which was, on the whole, standard in America grew up without
label: Paragraph

text: any great names being attached to it. Like tools and patent
label: Paragraph

text: furniture, it remained strictly anonymous. It is the out-
label: Paragraph

text: growth both of the urge for comfort in the dwelling and of the
label: Paragraph

text: American tendency to tackle problems directly. Frank Lloyd
label: Caption

text: Wright found the basic elements of the flexible ground plan
label: Paragraph

text: ready at hand in its anonymous development. Undoubtedly
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson gave a new artistic intensity to this sort of planning
label: Paragraph

text: in his houses of the early eighties — particularly those built
label: Paragraph

text: around Chicago and in New England. But open planning
label: Paragraph

text: itself, the flexible and informal ground plan — this is a product
label: Paragraph

text: of the American development as a whole.

text: During the eighties a whole colony of buildings suddenly sprang
label: Paragraph

text: up in Chicago — to heights of twelve, fourteen, sixteen, and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: isolation, as they were in other cities, but in close proximity to
label: Paragraph

text: each other. Each had its own individual appearance and its
label: Paragraph

text: own name, and yet the aggregate appearance was not chaotic.
label: Paragraph

text: American buildings are commonly so short-lived that in a few
label: Paragraph

text: decades, perhaps, these buildings will all have disappeared.
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the best specimens have gone already and many more
label: Paragraph

text: are destined to go soon.

text: form us of the state of development at the beginning and at the
label: Paragraph

text: end of this period.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: spread out behind it. At the time its great buildings went up,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and industrial structures of various kinds.

text: The Adler and Sullivan Auditorium marks one of the early

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: yault, thereby matching the auditorium proper.*™

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: building.”

text: We have been able to do no more here than simply point to

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: find in Europe. Progress in this direction was largely canceled

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In 1893 this Chicago architeclure impressed a French ob-
label: Paragraph

text: server — the novelist Paul Bourget — with “ the simple force of
label: Paragraph

text: need as a principle of beauty. . . . There is so little caprice
label: Paragraph

text: aud fancy in these monuments and these streets that they
label: Paragraph

text: seem to be the work of some impersonal power, irresistible,
label: Paragraph

text: unconscious, like a force of nature, in the service of which man
label: Paragraph

text: has been but a docile instrument. It is this expression of the
label: Paragraph

text: overpowering immensity of modern commerce which gives
label: Paragraph

text: to the city something of tragedy, and, to my feeling, a poetry.” ®
label: Paragraph

text: The Chicago school has many claims to importance. Its mem-
label: Paragraph

text: bers made the first expressive use of the new technical poten-
label: Paragraph

text: lialities in buildings which were permanent and essential parts
label: Paragraph

text: of the structure of Chicago’s daily life. They produced not
label: Paragraph

text: just a few isolated specimen structures but covered the whole
label: Paragraph

text: business district with a new architecture. Their work changed
label: Paragraph

text: the entire face of a great modern city.

label: Title

text: The architects of the Chicago school employed a new type of
label: Paragraph

text: construction: the iron skeleton. At that time it was called
label: Paragraph

text: quite simply “ Chicago construction.”
label: Paragraph

text: They invented a new kind of foundation to cope with the prob-
label: Paragraph

text: lem of the muddy ground of Chicago: the floating foundation.

label: Paragraph

text: They created the modern business and administration building,
label: Paragraph

text: The importance of the school for the history of architecture
label: Title

text: lies in this fact: for the first time in the nineteenth century the
label: Paragraph

text: schism between construction and architecture, between the
label: Paragraph

text: engineer and the architect, was healed. This schism marked
label: Paragraph

text: the whole preceding part of the century. With surprising
label: Paragraph

text: boldness, the Chicago school strove to break through to pure
label: Paragraph

text: forms, forms which would unite construction and architecture
label: Paragraph

text: in an identical expression.
label: Paragraph

text: These Chicago architects of the eighties were quite conscious
label: Paragraph

text: of their own boldness. In 1890 John Root — the constructor
label: Paragraph

text: of the Monadnock Block — said, speaking of modern business
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, that “‘ to lavish upon them profusion of delicate
label: Paragraph

text: ornament is worse than useless. . . . Rather should they by
label: Paragraph

text: their mass and proportion convey in some large elemental
label: Paragraph

text: sense an idea of the great, stable, conserving forces of modern
label: Paragraph

text: civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: “ One result of methods such as I have indicated will be the
label: Paragraph

text: resolution of our architectural designs into their essential ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments. So vital has the underlying structure of these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: become, that it must dictate absolutely the general departure
label: Paragraph

text: of external forms; and so imperative are all the commercial and
label: Paragraph

text: constructive demands, that all architectural detail employed
label: Paragraph

text: in expressing them must become modified by them. Under
label: Paragraph

text: these conditions we are compelled to work definitely with
label: Paragraph

text: definite aims, permeating ourselves with the full spirit of the
label: Paragraph

text: age, that we may give its architecture true art forms.” ©
label: Paragraph

text: The amount of work which came out of the Chicago school in
label: Paragraph

text: the course of its development was very great. We shall take
label: Paragraph

text: three buildings, each by a different architect but all showing
label: Paragraph

text: clearly the inherent urge of the Chicago school toward purity
label: Paragraph

text: of form.

text: The Leiter Building, 1889
label: Caption

text: William Le Baron Jenney not only produced the first example
label: Paragraph

text: of Chicago construction in his Home Insurance Building of
label: Paragraph

text: 1884-85, but he also erected the first building in which there
label: Paragraph

text: was not even one self-supporting wall, the Leiter Building.
label: Paragraph

text: With it purity of constructional methods seemed to find its
label: Paragraph

text: equivalent in architecture; the Leiter Building attains to an
label: Paragraph

text: expression in which the lingering memories of historical styles
label: Paragraph

text: play a negligible part.
label: Paragraph

text: The Leiter Building, planned in 1889, fills a whole block at
label: Paragraph

text: Van Buren and State streets (fig. 179). Jenney dealt with and
label: Paragraph

text: mastered a front four hundred feet long and eight stories high
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of great and simple units. The skeleton fur-
label: Paragraph

text: nishes the dominating accents of the building, appearing in
label: Paragraph

text: the huge squares into which the outer wall is divided. These
label: Paragraph

text: panels are filled by plate-glass windows which “ are separated
label: Paragraph

text: only by fireproofed metal columns.” *
label: Paragraph

text: The spirit behind this employment of the skeleton as an ar-
label: Paragraph

text: chitectonic means has received further development in con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary architecture. Le Corbusier’s Maison de Verre, a
label: Caption

text: Geneva apartment house of 1932, represents a later stage in its
label: Paragraph

text: evolution (fig. 180).
label: Paragraph

text: Jenney’s contemporaries seem to have recognized the signifi-
label: Paragraph

text: cance of his work. Even the anonymous author of Industrial
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago (1891) momentarily discards his accustomed sobriety
label: Paragraph

text: in speaking of it: “It has been constructed with the same
label: Paragraph

text: science and all the careful inspection that would be used in the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a steel railroad bridge of the first order. The
label: Paragraph

text: severely plain exterior is grand in its proportions. The great
label: Paragraph

text: corner piers are carried upward to a chaste cornice. Designed
label: Caption

text: for space, light, ventilation, and security, the Leiter Building
label: Caption

text: meets the object sought in every particular.” With its building,
label: Paragraph

text: he goes on to exclaim, “a giant structure . . . healthy to look

text: The Carson, Pirie, Scott store, one of the late productions of
label: Paragraph

text: the Chicago school, seems to be molded more by the anony-
label: Paragraph

text: mous spirit which ruled the work of that school than by Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s personal tendencies. In Sullivan’s best-known
label: Paragraph

text: buildings — from the Wainwright in St. Louis (1890-91) to
label: Paragraph

text: the Prudential in Buftalo (1894-95) and the Bayard Building
label: Paragraph

text: ‘in New York (1897-98) —- he continually increased the stress
label: Paragraph

text: upon the vertical elements in the design, emphasizing the piers
label: Paragraph

text: al the corners. He uses narrow pillars and gives the whole
label: Paragraph

text: building a strictly upward orientation, a movement as marked
label: Paragraph

text: as that which we encounter in the Gothic cathedrals.
label: Paragraph

text: But the skeleton — whether iron or steel or reinforced con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete — is essentially a neutral spatial network. Its “ cage
label: Paragraph

text: construction ” bounds a certain volume of space with complete
label: Paragraph

text: impartiality, and no one intrinsic direction. In his typical
label: Paragraph

text: buildings Sullivan picks out and emphasizes the vertical lines
label: Paragraph

text: of force in this network. In the Carson, Pirie, Scott store,
label: Paragraph

text: however, it is the neutral and impartial equilibrium inherent
label: Paragraph

text: in the skeleton construction which Sullivan chooses to project
label: Paragraph

text: upon the facade of the building.
label: Caption

text: The influence of the Chicago school was cut short by the in-
label: Paragraph

text: flux of eclecticism. Louis Sullivan — the great architect of
label: Paragraph

text: the school — did leave his mark upon the next generation of
label: Paragraph

text: architects in the Middle West. (Frank Lloyd Wright was to
label: Paragraph

text: emerge as the outstanding figure in this generation.) And
label: Paragraph

text: during the first decade of our century, the traditions of the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago school survived in works by some of its younger
label: Paragraph

text: members: George Elmslie, Hugh Garden, George Maher,
label: Title

text: Griffin, Thomas Tallmadge, and a few others. Some of their
label: Paragraph

text: buildings might have served as a revelation to the rising gen-
label: Paragraph

text: eration in Europe. They failed entirely, however, to influence
label: Paragraph

text: the corresponding groups in their own country. A literary
label: Paragraph

text: architectural education cut the younger men off from the
label: Paragraph

text: principles of the Chicago school and destroyed their individ-
label: Paragraph

text: uality as well. Left in isolation, the surviving members of the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago school grew discouraged, and many of them lost the
label: Paragraph

text: force which they had shown in a more favorable period.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1922 competition for the Chicago Tribune Building, the
label: Paragraph

text: plans of a competent American architect — Raymond Hood —
label: Caption

text: won the first prize. By this time, however, the confidence and
label: Paragraph

text: belief in its own forces which had sustained the Chicago school
label: Paragraph

text: had completely disappeared. The school might just as well
label: Paragraph

text: have never existed; its principles were crowded out by the
label: Paragraph

text: vogue of “ Woolworth Gothic.” #
label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: section of the country.
label: Paragraph

text: American architecture came under many different influences
label: Paragraph

text: during the ninetcenth century, but none was so strong or came
label: Paragraph

text: at such a critical moment as the rise to power of the mercantile
label: Paragraph

text: classicism developed in the East.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1893 World’s Fair elicited a variety of responses. The
label: Paragraph

text: public and most of the architects were rapturous in their de-
label: Paragraph

text: light. While I was in Chicago, one architect who had worked
label: Paragraph

text: on it quoted from memory the rather ironical comment of
label: Paragraph

text: William James: ‘‘ Everyone says one ouglit to sell all one has
label: Paragraph

text: and mortgage one’s soul to go there; it is esteemed such a
label: Paragraph

text: revelation of beauty. People cast away all sin and baseness,
label: Paragraph

text: burst into tears, and grow religious, etc., under the influence.”
label: Paragraph

text: Some European observers were more sceptical. The extremely
label: Paragraph

text: well-informed Belgian constructer Vierendeel found both its
label: Paragraph

text: staff architecture and the construction it enveloped timid and
label: Paragraph

text: secondhand — as we saw toward the end of our discussion of
label: Paragraph

text: the great nineteenth-century exhibitions.
label: Paragraph

text: The lonely American voices raised against the unexampled
label: Title

text: seduction of the public taste underlying the Fair’s pseudo-
label: Paragraph

text: splendor went unheard. Louis Sullivan said bitterly that “ the
label: Paragraph

text: damage wrought to this country by the Chicago World’s Fair
label: Title

text: will last half a century.” At the time this may have seemed
label: Paragraph

text: only the exaggerated expression of an outraged artist; it turned
label: Paragraph

text: out to be a precise prophecy of what was actually to follow.
label: Paragraph

text: Public, artists, and literary people believed themselves to be
label: Paragraph

text: witnessing a splendid rebirth of the great traditions of past
label: Paragraph

text: ages. The immense appeal of this re-created past in “ the
label: Paragraph

text: White City ” can only be laid to a quite unnecessary national
label: Paragraph

text: inferiority complex. It was the same feeling — reinforced by
label: Paragraph

text: the prestige of the Paris exhibition of 1889 — which gave the
label: Paragraph

text: French academicians a dominating role at this Chicago fair.
label: Paragraph

text: The contemporary biographer of John Root expresses it
label: Paragraph

text: quite clearly: “At that time few hoped to rival Paris; the
label: Paragraph

text: artistic capacity and experience of the French made us dis-
label: Paragraph

text: irustful of ourselves. We should have a great American fair,
label: Paragraph

text: but in points of grouping and design we must expect inferiority
label: Paragraph

text: to French taste.” 1 And it was to France that the builders of
label: Paragraph

text: the Fair turned in their search for beauty. Its beautics were
label: Paragraph

text: taken out of the preserve jars of the Académie des Beaux-Arts
label: Caption

text: -— where they had been laid up during what was certainly its
label: Paragraph

text: worst period. Grand prix de Rome facades were copied, and
label: Paragraph

text: men like Burnham (who had assisted in raising the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: school to a level much higher than the Academy’s) acted like
label: Paragraph

text: docile children in the presence of the French masters. All
label: Paragraph

text: this is another instance of the split between thought and feeling
label: Paragraph

text: in the nineteenth century. Only Louis Sullivan had sufficient
label: Paragraph

text: inner strength to hold fast in the midst of a general surrender.
label: Paragraph

text: But his Transportation Building for the Chicago fair marked
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of his unpopularity as an architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Mercantile classicism had been developing and gaining sLrength
label: Paragraph

text: in New York since the eighties, but it won its country-wide
label: Paragraph

text: ascendency at the World’s Columbian Exhibition of 1893.77
label: Caption

text: The spirit behind it had now come to possess authority for
label: Paragraph

text: American architecture as a whole.”* The Fair should, indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: have stood in New York; it so thoroughly represented the in-
label: Paragraph

text: fluence of that city. But as soon as a Columbian exposition
label: Paragraph

text: was proposed, the people of Chicago leaped at the idea. “‘ The
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm of the city was set on its mettle; an aggressive
label: Paragraph

text: campaign was organized, and five million dollars pledged by
label: Paragraph

text: private subscription before other cities had begun to act.” 7
label: Caption

text: The hypnotic spell which mercantile classicism exerted appears
label: Paragraph

text: from some lines in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Autobiography.

text: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT
label: Title

text: Wright and the American Development
label: Title

text: Of all present-day architects whose span of work reachcs back
label: Paragraph

text: into the nineteenth century, Frank Lloyd Wright is without
label: Paragraph

text: doubt the most farsighted, a genius of inexplicably rich and
label: Paragraph

text: continuing vitality. He ranges the wide expanse of historical
label: Paragraph

text: interrelations, drawing particularly upon the architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: the Far East — not, however, in the manner of the last cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury, as a substitute for creative impulse, but, like Matisse
label: Paragraph

text: with negro or Persian art, out of an inner sympathetic relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship. At the same time he springs out of the American soil and
label: Paragraph

text: the American tradition more directly perhaps than any other
label: Paragraph

text: of the great American architects. True insight into his work
label: Paragraph

text: demands a somewhat subtle approach, for Wright’s dominat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing personality, present in every touch of what he does, is
label: Paragraph

text: not at all simple. He bears in himself the marks of the late
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century; yet isolated and singlehanded, without
label: Paragraph

text: aid from his contemporaries among painters and sculptors, he
label: Paragraph

text: has introduced the beginnings of a new conception.
label: Paragraph

text: When he began work in 1887, he was — in Chicago — at the
label: Paragraph

text: very center, the fountainhead, of architectural development.
label: Paragraph

text: Ie was apprentice in the atelier of two of the best men, Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan, “ lieber Meister,”’ he calls him, and Dankmar Adler,
label: Paragraph

text: the grand old chief,” at the very time when they were on the
label: Paragraph

text: ascendant creatively, working on the Auditorium Building.
label: Paragraph

text: He had as the principal influence of his youth the culmination
label: Paragraph

text: of the Chicago renascence. And yet when he began to work
label: Paragraph

text: independently, Wright did not continue directly in the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: school; he did not carry over the use of the new materials —
label: Paragraph

text: the iron skeleton and the great glass surfaces of the office
label: Caption

text: buildings — into his own sphere: housing. Instead he was
label: Paragraph

text: rather conservative; in many respects he followed Richardson
label: Paragraph

text: more than Sullivan. It was not until as late as the thirties,
label: Paragraph

text: when European architects were already utilizing the inherent
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities of ferroconcrete to the fullest, that Wright, as he
label: Paragraph

text: says himself, used it for the first time to any great extent for
label: Paragraph

text: one of his houses.*! This was duc not to any lack of technical
label: Paragraph

text: ability but to his own will and character.
label: Paragraph

text: * The Kaufman house, “ Falling Water,” Bear Run, Pennsylvania, 1937.
label: Caption

text: In Europe Wright was very shortly accepted and understood
label: Paragraph

text: by the generation which was responsible for the modern move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment. In 1908 he was visited by Kuno Francke, then a German
label: Paragraph

text: exchange professor lecturing at Harvard University on aesthet-
label: Paragraph

text: ics. The result of this visit was the publication in Germany in
label: Paragraph

text: 1910 of a monumental work on Wright’s architecture.” This
label: Paragraph

text: was supplemented in 1911 by a smaller work on the same sub-
label: Paragraph

text: ject, which enjoyed a very wide circulalion.* These two books
label: Paragraph

text: marked the beginning of Wright’s forcign influence; the book
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1910 has not since been approached in compre-
label: Paragraph

text: hensiveness.
label: Paragraph

text: What is the explanation of the fact that Wright is the only
label: Paragraph

text: architect so far ahead of his own generation, a man who is even
label: Paragraph

text: today creating works that have a strong impact? The answer
label: Paragraph

text: is rather simple: he had less debris to clear away than the
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans. He had been born in the Middle West, within the
label: Paragraph

text: shadow of the place possessing the greatest architectural vital-
label: Paragraph

text: ity of the period: Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: From the outset Wright devoted himself to the problem which
label: Paragraph

text: was to be his life interest — the house as a shelter. He had at
label: Paragraph

text: his disposal the anonymous American tradition, the example of

text: The Cruciform and the Elongated Plan
label: Title

text: Before I had seen any of Wright’s houses, I stopped once for a
label: Paragraph

text: rest ina hunting lodge in the Vermont hills. It had an immense
label: Paragraph

text: stone chimney which stood massively in its center, rising the
label: Paragraph

text: entire height from the ground up through the roof. The in-
label: Paragraph

text: terior space was undivided, except for a partition which cut
label: Paragraph

text: off the kitchen and the sleeping room. There was no ceiling,
label: Paragraph

text: but simply open rafters from which hung fox and bear skins.
label: Paragraph

text: At that moment I began to understand the way Wright con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceives his interior spaces. He works fundamentally and as far
label: Paragraph

text: as possible with the house as one room. Its inner space is dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferentiated to meet special needs. As he points out, he “ de-
label: Paragraph

text: clared the whole . . . floor as one room, cutting off the kitchen
label: Paragraph

text: as a laboratory, putting servants’ sleeping and living quarters
label: Paragraph

text: next to it, semi-detached, on the ground floor, screening vari-
label: Caption

text: ous portions in the big room, for certain domestic purposes —
label: Paragraph

text: like dining or reading, or receiving a formal caller.”’ 87
label: Paragraph

text: In organizing his plans Wright goes back to the seventeenth
label: Paragraph

text: century in the use of the Jarge chimney in the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: house as starting point for the whole layout. He spreads out
label: Paragraph

text: the different rooms from this massive kernel. What first im-
label: Paragraph

text: pressed European architects was his “‘ windmill” plan, so
label: Paragraph

text: called because of the way the rooms were extended outward
label: Paragraph

text: from the center like the vanes of a windmill (fig. 189). This
label: Paragraph

text: “windmill ” plan is really cruciform, an interpenetration of
label: Paragraph

text: two parts of the house, which cut each other transversely to
label: Paragraph

text: form a cross. Often they are of different heights; then the
label: Paragraph

text: effect is of one crossbar superimposed upon and penetrating
label: Paragraph

text: the other.
label: Paragraph

text: This early American practice of using a central chimney as the
label: Paragraph

text: core of the house, as the point about which the whole is or-
label: Paragraph

text: ganized, was kept alive also through the nineteenth century
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 187). Again we may cite as evidence one of those unknown
label: Paragraph

text: writers who reflect the common taste. In one of the small
label: Paragraph

text: popular books on suburban and country houses in the early
label: Paragraph

text: seventies, there is proposed a country house built completely
label: Paragraph

text: around a fourfold, four-sided chimney, with rooms leading off
label: Caption

text: in wings from each of the four sides. The author’s reason for
label: Paragraph

text: this cruciform arrangement is very close to Wright’s own
label: Paragraph

text: intention, both in the stress placed upon light — Wright em-
label: Paragraph

text: phasizes the fact that rooms in his layout can get light from
label: Paragraph

text: three sides — and in the urge to treat the several rooms as a
label: Paragraph

text: unit: “ The design of this house was made for the purpose of
label: Paragraph

text: giving each room a sunny southern exposure, and out of ten
label: Paragraph

text: rooms nine have at least one lookout to the southeast. The
label: Paragraph

text: principal floor is so managed that the spacious hall with wind-
label: Paragraph

text: ing staircase presents an attractive feature on entering. The
label: Paragraph

text: chimney is in the center of the house and sliding doors connect
label: Paragraph

text: each of the principal rooms so that when occasion requires, hall,
label: Paragraph

text: parlor, library, and dining room may be thrown together, the
label: Paragraph

text: “ Modern Architecture (Princeton, 1931), Princeton Monographs in Art and Archae-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Of these, the Isabel Roberts house in River Forest, Illinois
label: Caption

text: (figs. 189, 190), one of the most charming of Wright’s smaller
label: Paragraph

text: houses, shows an interesting employment of the interpenetra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of two volumes of different heights, in which Wright uses
label: Paragraph

text: the higher volume to mold, not the hallway, but the space of
label: Paragraph

text: the living room from the ground up through the whole height
label: Paragraph

text: to the inner planes of the roof (fig. 191). It represents an effort
label: Paragraph

text: to satisfy the feeling of a need for the full height as living
label: Paragraph

text: space. This feeling finds expression not only in the houses of
label: Paragraph

text: American settlers of the seventeenth century but in many
label: Paragraph

text: early civilizations, and it has reappearcd in our own period.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright was one of the first to recognize this feeling, to for-
label: Paragraph

text: mulate it and give it expression. In the Isabel Roberts house
label: Caption

text: the living room dominates, rising up to the gently sloping roof,
label: Paragraph

text: and divided in height by a gallery, so that there are recessed
label: Paragraph

text: spaces both above and below. This gives an unaccustomed
label: Paragraph

text: and new plasticity to the whole room, which is enhanced by the
label: Paragraph

text: use of various planes in different materials—the brick faccof the
label: Paragraph

text: chimney, the several wall surfaces, and the slope of the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright himself never abandoned the idea of the house spread
label: Paragraph

text: out from a central core. When in 1939 he built a low-cost four-
label: Paragraph

text: family housing unit (Suntop Houses, Ardmore, Pa.; figs. 192,
label: Caption

text: 193),°° he separated the different apartments by brick walls
label: Paragraph

text: crossing at right angles. At the central core he put not a chim-
label: Paragraph

text: ney but all the utilities — plumbing, heating, electricity, and
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation — so that they were concentrated in the darkest
label: Paragraph

text: spot in the building.
label: Paragraph

text: When it is possible, Wright likes to spread his structures out
label: Paragraph

text: freely over the ground. In the introduction to the study of his
label: Paragraph

text: work published in Berlin in 1910, he points out that the first
label: Paragraph

text: floor was often built principally as a cellar. The main living
label: Paragraph

text: quarters lie in the upper story on one floor, as in the Coonley
label: Paragraph

text: house (1911), where only the entrance hall and the game room
label: Paragraph

text: are on the ground floor; in Taliesin, his own house, they are
label: Paragraph

text: set into and connected with the ground. This led him to the
label: Paragraph

text: flexible and informal ground plan so deeply embedded in the
label: Paragraph

text: American architectural development from its beginning. As a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of this development Wright now let the different
label: Paragraph

text: rooms flow out horizontally, just as, in houses like the Isabel
label: Paragraph

text: Roberts house, he had molded them vertically.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1910 Wright had achieved a flexibility of open planning
label: Paragraph

text: unapproached hitherto. In other countries at that time the
label: Paragraph

text: flexible ground plan and the flexibly molded interior and ex-
label: Paragraph

text: terior were almost unknown. Wright’s realization of a flexible
label: Paragraph

text: treatment of the inner space of a building is probably his
label: Paragraph

text: greatest service to architecture. It brought life, movement,
label: Paragraph

text: freedom into the whole rigid and benumbed body of modern
label: Title

text: architecture.

label: Caption

text: In this house, which has had far-reaching influence, Wright has used plane surfaces at dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferent depths, advancing and receding. The Robie house, a town villa, is in close relation
label: Paragraph

text: to the aims of the Chicago school.
label: Paragraph

text: Americans like a strong and unbroken horizontal line equally
label: Paragraph

text: in their houses and in the Pullman car.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright adopts the porch for his houses — not, however, en-
label: Paragraph

text: circling his buildings with it, but pushing it forward, in keep-
label: Paragraph

text: ing with his cruciform or elongated plans, as an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: the wings. Very often it thrusts out into space as a pure canti-
label: Paragraph

text: lever hovering above the earth. Such a treatment had never
label: Paragraph

text: been altemp led before. True, it is the old element of the porch
label: Paragraph

text: but it is not simply something attached to the house; rather it
label: Paragraph

text: is am essential part of the structure, molded as an inseparable
label: Paragraph

text: part of il. For several reasons, which he has explained over
label: Paragraph

text: and over in his writings, Wright uses overhanging eaves. He
label: Paragraph

text: treats them, too, as horizontal planes — “ broad protecting
label: Paragraph

text: roof shelters,” as he calls them — just as Burnham, before he
label: Paragraph

text: turned classicist, roofed his Reliance Building with a thin
label: Paragraph

text: slab (fig. 181).
label: Paragraph

text: To these hovering horizontal elements Wright has added the
label: Paragraph

text: plane of vertical surfaces. When he built the Charnley house
label: Paragraph

text: in 1892 (fig. 186), he used the clean-cut level surfaces of the
label: Paragraph

text: American tradition. But soon he became more daring, espe-
label: Paragraph

text: cially in his elongated schemes, such as the D. D. Martin house
label: Paragraph

text: in Buffalo (1904), and in the house which has had perhaps the
label: Paragraph

text: most far-reaching influence of all his works, the Robie house, a
label: Paragraph

text: town villa on Woodlawn Avenue, Chicago (fig. 196). In the
label: Caption

text: nineteenth century the exterior of the American house was not
label: Paragraph

text: up to the level of the floor plan in quality and artistic expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion. Wright brought about a change. He took the plane
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces presented to him and organized them variously, mul-
label: Paragraph

text: tiplying them, intersecting them or placing them in different
label: Paragraph

text: depths one behind another, incorporating the plane of the
label: Paragraph

text: garden wall with the different advancing and receding planes
label: Paragraph

text: of the house itself so that often its solid volume is not at all
label: Paragraph

text: apparent. This handling is not without relation to what was
label: Paragraph

text: being explored in space conceptions in France during the very
label: Paragraph

text: years when Wright was building the Robie house. To speak of
label: Paragraph

text: his houses of the late Chicago period as being in the “ prairie
label: Paragraph

text: style,” as having been inspired by the long lines of the prairie,
label: Paragraph

text: is a pat explanation, but it does not go to the root of the mat-
label: Paragraph

text: ter. The forms of the Robie house, the long horizontal bands,
label: Paragraph

text: the series of windows, the garden walls, are sharply cut as if
label: Paragraph

text: by a machine. These houses are to be explained as a pure
label: Paragraph

text: arlistic expression which is deeply connected with the anony-
label: Paragraph

text: mous aims of their period.
label: Paragraph

text: Chicagoans who did not like the Robie house, who were of-
label: Paragraph

text: fended by the novelty of its appearance and its long stretched-
label: Paragraph

text: out horizontal lines, sought to deride it by comparing it to a
label: Paragraph

text: steamship, just as later Le Corbusicr’s critics were to refer
label: Paragraph

text: similarly to his buildings. Without knowing it, they were im-
label: Paragraph

text: plying that the house was built in the spirit of the age out of
label: Paragraph

text: which it came, that, like the steamship, it had been born
label: Paragraph

text: naturally out of its period. What is decisive in it is not a super-
label: Paragraph

text: ficial and misunderstood similarity to a steamship but its inner
label: Paragraph

text: relationship with the aims of its time. The warehouse of Mont-
label: Paragraph

text: gomery, Ward and Company (fig. 195), with its unbroken
label: Paragraph

text: front of eight hundred feet and the undisguised expression of
label: Paragraph

text: its structural body,” was built in the same year (1908) as the
label: Paragraph

text: Robie house.
label: Paragraph

text: From the beginuing Wright treated the inner as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: outer wall as a plane surface. It never occurred to him to do
label: Paragraph

text: what European architects did about 1896 —- replace rococo
label: Paragraph

text: decoration with the serpentine lines of the art nouveau. In his
label: Paragraph

text: interiors, too, there is a constant endeavor to find interrcla-
label: Paragraph

text: tions between the various separate elements — walls, ceilings,
label: Paragraph

text: windows, and door openings. Different ceiling heights are some-
label: Paragraph

text: times introduced into the same room, a treatment which paral-
label: Paragraph

text: lels Wright's use of horizontal planes at different heights, such
label: Paragraph

text: as cantilevered porches, overhanging caves, and levels varying
label: Paragraph

text: according to the grades of the site.

text: The Urge toward the Organic
label: Title

text: Throughout history there persist two distinct trends — the
label: Paragraph

text: one toward the rational and the geometrical, the other toward
label: Paragraph

text: the irrational and the organic: two different ways of dealing
label: Title

text: with or of mastering the environment. These contrasting ap-
label: Paragraph

text: proaches to the problem have been evident in all cultures,
label: Paragraph

text: both early and late. Since the beginning of civilization there
label: Paragraph

text: have been cities planned according to regular schemes and
label: Paragraph

text: cities which have grown up organically like trees. The ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Greeks put their mathematically proportioned temples on the
label: Paragraph

text: top of rocky acropolises, outlined against their southern skies;
label: Paragraph

text: the villages of the Greek islands, whitewashed on the crests of
label: Paragraph

text: hills, are easily distinguishable far out at sea because of their
label: Paragraph

text: clearly marked and periodically rewhitened walls.
label: Paragraph

text: The difference between organic and geometrical perceptions
label: Title

text: is present even today in contemporary painting and contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary architecture. They are constantly recurrent ways of
label: Paragraph

text: approach; one cannot be considered superior to the other. The
label: Paragraph

text: artist has the right of choice, of saying according to his own
label: Paragraph

text: point of view which pleases him and which he will follow.
label: Paragraph

text: From the beginning Frank Lloyd Wright has faced toward an
label: Paragraph

text: organic perception of the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s whole career has been an endeavor to express himself
label: Paragraph

text: in what he calls “ organic architecture,” whatever that may be.
label: Paragraph

text: fe likes to work within the shadow of this feeling. As recently
label: Paragraph

text: as January 25, 1940, when he lectured in Jackson Hall, Boston,
label: Paragraph

text: he devoted his entire discussion to this problem of his life. He
label: Paragraph

text: tried by a sort of Socratic dialogue, a give-and-take between
label: Paragraph

text: himself and his audience, to define and explain it. But his
label: Paragraph

text: effort was fulile. It was clear, finally, that no explanation was
label: Paragraph

text: possible in words, that what he meant by organic architecture
label: Paragraph

text: could be revealed only in his work.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 1900 Louis Sullivan, in his Kindergarten Chals,™ sought
label: Paragraph

text: to arrive at “ the true meaning of the words ‘ Organic Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture’ ” through contrast, by exploring “ what the word ‘ or-
label: Paragraph

text: ganic’ doesn’t mean.” Organic, he said, means living, means
label: Paragraph

text: devclopment, and not, as in the reigning American architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of 1900, “ pitiful in its folly, . . . functions without
label: Paragraph

text: forms, forms without functions; details unrelated to masses,
label: Paragraph

text: and masses unrelated to anything but folly... .” Of this he
label: Paragraph

text: adds: ‘‘ Organic it is not. Inorganic it is becoming.’ “ Or-
label: Paragraph

text: ganic” means for him the “ searching for realities, — a word
label: Paragraph

text: I love because I love the sense of life it stands for, the ten-
label: Paragraph

text: fingered grasp of things it implies... .” “ Organic,” in the
label: Paragraph

text: sense of Sullivan and of Wright, is a protest against the split
label: Paragraph

text: personality, against a split culture. It is identical with “ the
label: Paragraph

text: ten-fingered grasp of reality’ or with that development in
label: Paragraph

text: which thinking and fecling approach coincidence.

text: This urge toward the organic may partly explain why Wright

text: The usual criticism of the houses of his Chicago period — the

label: Paragraph

text: and its heavily glassed-in areas. In his houses and even his

text: structure, but to seal it rather than to open it up.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Office Buildings
label: Title

text: Frank Lloyd Wright’s distinctively individual feeling for the
label: Paragraph

text: house as a shelter and his handling of it as an enclosed spatial
label: Paragraph

text: unit are reflected in his two office buildings — the Larkin Soap
label: Paragraph

text: Company administration building in Buffalo (1904; fig. 200)
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: Racine, Wisconsin (1939; fig. 201). Though they were erected
label: Paragraph

text: a quarter of a century apart and are very different in appear-
label: Paragraph

text: ance, they show the same spirit and give an equal insight into
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s architectural treatment. Both are treated primarily
label: Paragraph

text: as one room; both are separated from the outdoors; both are
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed by massive walls and receive their light through sky-
label: Paragraph

text: lights and high-placed windows or glass tubing. They are
label: Paragraph

text: shells shutting out the outer world, isolated and self-contained
label: Paragraph

text: units, and thus in the slrongest contrast, on the one hand, to
label: Paragraph

text: the buildings of the Chicago school of the eighties with their
label: Paragraph

text: wide open glass areas and, on the other, to the designs of the
label: Paragraph

text: European movement of the twenties.
label: Paragraph

text: The Larkin Building stands a resolutely independent mass
label: Paragraph

text: embraced by the extended wings of the much larger factory
label: Paragraph

text: building of the company. There is an interplay between the
label: Paragraph

text: volume of its spatial unit and the square towers at either end
label: Paragraph

text: and flanking the entrance. These towers, which encase the
label: Paragraph

text: stairways and rise starkly without interruption upward over a
label: Paragraph

text: hundred feet, were the despair of contemporary critics, who
label: Paragraph

text: protested that they thrust up so strongly that there was no
label: Paragraph

text: play of light and shadow, and who thought that they should
label: Paragraph

text: be relieved by moldings or softened by glazed tiles in a variety
label: Paragraph

text: of color patterns.°’ The building itself had for these critics a
label: Paragraph

text: erimness of aspect which repelled them. It was for them an
label: Paragraph

text: “accumulation of strange sharp-edged solids, offering no
label: Paragraph

text: modulation of surface,” ils features “ the square corner, the
label: Paragraph

text: right angle, the straight edge, the sharp arris, the firm vertical
label: Paragraph

text: and horizontal lines, unbroken, unmodified, uncompromising
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: THE NEW SPACE CONCEPTION: SPACE-TIME
label: Title

text: Social, economic, and functional influences play a vital part
label: Paragraph

text: in all human activities, from the sciences to the arts. But there
label: Paragraph

text: are other factors which also have to be taken into account —
label: Paragraph

text: our feelings and emotions. These factors are often dismissed
label: Paragraph

text: as trivial, but actually their effect upon men’s actions is im-
label: Paragraph

text: mense. A good share of the misfortunes of the past century
label: Paragraph

text: came out of its belief that industry and techniques had only a
label: Paragraph

text: functional import, with no emotional content. The arts were
label: Paragraph

text: exiled to an isolated realm of their own, completely insulated
label: Paragraph

text: from everyday realities. As a result, life lost unity and bal-
label: Paragraph

text: ance; science and industry made steady advances, but in the
label: Paragraph

text: now detached realm of feeling there was nothing but a vacil-
label: Paragraph

text: lation from one extreme to the other.
label: Paragraph

text: The scope and strength of the emotions are both greater than
label: Paragraph

text: we sometimes suppose. Emotion or feeling enters into all our
label: Paragraph

text: affairs — speculation is never completely “‘ pure,” just as
label: Paragraph

text: action is never entirely practical. And, of course, we are far
label: Paragraph

text: from having free choice in this matter of feeling. Large tracts
label: Paragraph

text: of our emotional life are determined by circumstances over
label: Paragraph

text: which we have no control: by the fact that we happen to be
label: Paragraph

text: men, of such or such a kind, living at this or that period. Thus
label: Paragraph

text: a thoroughly integrated culture produces a marked unity of
label: Paragraph

text: feeling among its representatives. For example, a recognizable
label: Paragraph

text: common spirit runs through the whole baroque period. It
label: Paragraph

text: makes itself felt in activities as distinct from each other as
label: Paragraph

text: painting and philosophy or architecture and mathematics.
label: Paragraph

text: This is not particularly surprising. Techniques, sciences, the
label: Paragraph

text: arts — all these are carried on by men who have grown up
label: Paragraph

text: together in the same period, exposed to its characteristic in-
label: Paragraph

text: fluences. The feelings which it is the special concern of the
label: Paragraph

text: artist to express are also at work within the engineer and the
label: Paragraph

text: mathematician. This emotional background shared by such
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise divergent pursuits is what we must try to discover.
label: Paragraph

text: Do We Need Artists?
label: Title

text: Some people question whether any pervasive unity of feeling is
label: Paragraph

text: possible in a period like ours. They regard science and industry
label: Paragraph

text: as inimical to art and feeling: where the former prosper, the
label: Paragraph

text: latter decline. Or they see science taking over the arts, opening
label: Paragraph

text: up new means of self-expression which make us independent of
label: Paragraph

text: them. There is some basis for views like these. It is obvious
label: Paragraph

text: that the serious artist plays no very important role in con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary life — usually he cannot even make a living by his
label: Paragraph

text: work. At the same time, this civilization is too intimately a
label: Paragraph

text: part of us to be simply abandoned. Do we, then, really need
label: Paragraph

text: artists any longer?
label: Title

text: In any civilization, feeling continues to filter through every
label: Paragraph

text: activity and situation. An environment whose chief aspects
label: Paragraph

text: remain opaque to feeling is as unsatisfying as one which resists
label: Paragraph

text: practical or intellectual control. But just this sort of emotional
label: Paragraph

text: frustration has prevailed for a long time past. An official art
label: Paragraph

text: has turned its back upon the contemporary world and given up
label: Paragraph

text: the attempt to interpret it emotionally. The feelings which
label: Paragraph

text: that world elicits have remained formless, have never met with
label: Paragraph

text: those objects which are at once their symbols and their satis-
label: Paragraph

text: faction.
label: Paragraph

text: Such symbols, however, are vital necessities. Feelings build
label: Paragraph

text: up within us and form systems; they cannot be discharged
label: Paragraph

text: through instantaneous animal outcries or grimaces. We need
label: Paragraph

text: to discover harmonies between our own inner states and our
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. And no level of development can be maintained
label: Paragraph

text: if it remains detached from our emotional life. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: machinery runs down.
label: Paragraph

text: This is the reason why the most familiar and ordinary things
label: Paragraph

text: have importance for the genuinely creative artists of our gen-
label: Paragraph

text: eration. Painters like Picasso, Juan Gris, the lyricist. of cub-
label: Paragraph

text: ism, and Le Corbusier have devoted themselves to the common
label: Paragraph

text: objects of daily use: bowls, pipes, bottles, glasses, guitars.
label: Paragraph

text: Natural materials have received the same attention: stones
label: Paragraph

text: holNowed out by the sea, roots, bits of bark — even weather-
label: Paragraph

text: bleached bones. Anonymous and unpretentious things like
label: Paragraph

text: these scarcely figure at all in our normal consciousness, but
label: Paragraph

text: they attain their true stature and significance under the artist’s
label: Paragraph

text: hand. They become revealed as objets & réaction poéliques, to
label: Paragraph

text: borrow Le Corbusier’s phrase. Or, to put it somewhat dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferently, new parts of the world are made accessible to feeling.
label: Paragraph

text: The opening up of such new realms of feeling has always been
label: Paragraph

text: the artist’s chicf mission. A great deal of our world would lack
label: Paragraph

text: all emotional significance if it were not for his work. As re-
label: Paragraph

text: cently as the eighteenth century, mountain scenery was felt to
label: Paragraph

text: exhibit nothing except a formless and alarming confusion.
label: Paragraph

text: Winckelmann, the discoverer of Greck art, could not bear to
label: Paragraph

text: look out the windows of his carriage when he crossed the Alps
label: Paragraph

text: into aly, around 1760. Ue found the jumbled granite masses
label: Paragraph

text: of the St. Gotthard so frightful that he pulled down the blinds
label: Paragraph

text: and sat back to await the smooth outlines of the Italian coun-
label: Paragraph

text: tryside. A century later, Ruskin was seeking out the moun-
label: Paragraph

text: tains of Chamonix as a refuge from an industrial world that
label: Paragraph

text: made no kind of aesthetic sense. Ships, bridges, iron con-
label: Paragraph

text: structions — the new artistic potentialities of his period, in
label: Paragraph

text: short — these were the things Ruskin pulled down the blinds
label: Paragraph

text: on. Right now there are great areas of our experience which
label: Paragraph

text: are still waiting to be claimed by feeling. Thus we are no
label: Paragraph

text: longer limited to seeing objects from the distances normal for
label: Paragraph

text: earth-bound animals. The bird’s-eye view has opened up to us
label: Paragraph

text: whole new aspects of the world. Such new modes of perception
label: Paragraph

text: carry with them new feelings which the artist must formulate.
label: Paragraph

text: The artist, in fact, functions a great deal like an inventor or a
label: Paragraph

text: scientific discoverer: all three seck new relations between
label: Title

text: man and his world. In the artist’s case these relations are
label: Paragraph

text: emotional instead of practical or cognitive. The creative art-
label: Paragraph

text: ist does not want to copy his surroundings, on the one hand, or
label: Paragraph

text: to make us see them through his eyes, on the other. He is a
label: Paragraph

text: specialist who shows us in his work as if in a mirror some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing we have not realized for ourselves: the state of our own
label: Paragraph

text: souls. He finds the outer symbols for the feelings which really
label: Paragraph

text: possess us but which for us are only chaotic and — therefore
label: Paragraph

text: —disquicling, obsessive stirrings. This is why we still need
label: Paragraph

text: artists, however difficult it may be for them to hold their place
label: Paragraph

text: in the modern world.
label: Paragraph

text: But if the artist is so necessary to us, how is it that he seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have lost contact with all but a small number of his contem-
label: Paragraph

text: poraries? Ordinary people make it almost a point of pride to
label: Paragraph

text: insist that, so far as they are concerned, his vocabulary of
label: Paragraph

text: forms is totally incomprehensible.
label: Paragraph

text: This is often said to be a consequence of the revolt against
label: Paragraph

text: naturalism. Actually, however, it dates from quite another

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Cut off from the crafts, the artist was faced with the serious
label: Paragraph

text: problem of competing with the factory system for his living.
label: Paragraph

text: One solution was to set himself up in the luxury trades, to
label: Paragraph

text: cater, quite unashamed, to the lowest common denominator of
label: Paragraph

text: public taste. Art-to-public-order flooded the world, filled the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The most favored of these cultivated drudges —a Meisso-
label: Paragraph

text: nier, for example — sometimes saw their canvases sold at a
label: Paragraph

text: thousand francs the square inch.
label: Paragraph

text: As far as the public and the critics were concerned, this was
label: Paragraph

text: art — and this the work the artist was meant to do. The half-
label: Paragraph

text: dozen painters who carried on the arList’s real work of invention
label: Paragraph

text: and research were absolutely ignored. The constituent facts
label: Paragraph

text: in the painting of our period were developed against the will
label: Paragraph

text: of the public and almost in secret. And this from the begin-
label: Paragraph

text: ning to the end of the century, from Ingres to Cézanne.
label: Paragraph

text: The same situation held for architecture. Here too the ad-
label: Paragraph

text: vances were made surreptitiously, in the department of con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction. The architect and the painter were faced with the
label: Paragraph

text: same long struggle against trompe l’eil. Both had to combat
label: Paragraph

text: entrenched styles by returning to the pure means of expression.
label: Paragraph

text: For some four decades painter after painter makes the effort
label: Paragraph

text: lo reconquer the plane surface. We have seen how the same
label: Paragraph

text: struggle arose in architecture as a consequence of the demand
label: Paragraph

text: for morality. Painters very different in type but sharing a
label: Paragraph

text: common isolation from the public worked steadily toward a
label: Paragraph

text: new conceplion of space. And no one can understand con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary architecture, become aware of the feelings hidden
label: Paragraph

text: behind it, unless he has grasped the spirit animating this
label: Paragraph

text: painting.
label: Paragraph

text: The fact that modern painting bewilders the public is not
label: Paragraph

text: strange: for a full century the public has ignored all the devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opments which have led up to it, There would be cause for
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: THE RESEARCH INTO SPACE: CUBISM
label: Title

text: In many places, about 1910, a consciousness thal the painter’s
label: Paragraph

text: means of expression had lost contact with modern life was
label: Paragraph

text: beginning to emerge. But it was in Paris, with cubism, that
label: Paragraph

text: these efforts first attained a visible result. The method of
label: Paragraph

text: presenting spatial relationships which the cubists developed
label: Paragraph

text: has furnished the plastic principles of present-day visual
label: Paragraph

text: approach.!
label: Paragraph

text: The half-century previous to the rise of cubism had seen paint-
label: Paragraph

text: ing flourish almost nowhere outside of France. It was the high
label: Paragraph

text: cullure of painting that grew up in France during this period
label: Paragraph

text: which formed the fostering soil for our contemporary art.
label: Paragraph

text: Young people of talent — whether Spanish like Picasso, or
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss like Le Corbusier — found their inspiration in Paris, in
label: Paragraph

text: the union of their powers with the artistic tradition of that
label: Paragraph

text: city. The vitality of French culture served to the advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: the whole world. Among the general public, however, there
label: Paragraph

text: was no sympathetic response to this achievement. It was from
label: Paragraph

text: a form of art which the public despised that nineteenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: painting drew its positive strength. Cubism, growing up in
label: Paragraph

text: this soil, absorbed all its vigor.
label: Paragraph

text: Picasso has been called the inventor of cubism, but cubism
label: Paragraph

text: is not the invention of any individual. It is rather the expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of a collective and almost unconscious attitude. A painter
label: Paragraph

text: who participated in the movement says of its beginnings:
label: Paragraph

text: “ There was no invention. Still more, there could not be one.
label: Paragraph

text: Soon it was twitching in everybody’s fingers. There was a
label: Paragraph

text: presentiment of what should come, and experiments were made.
label: Paragraph

text: We avoided one another; a discovery was on the point of being

text: From the Renaissance to the first decade of the present cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury perspective had been one of the most important constit-
label: Paragraph

text: uent facts in painting. It had remained a constant element
label: Paragraph

text: through all changes of style. The four-century-old habit of
label: Paragraph

text: secing the outer world in the Renaissance manner — that is,
label: Paragraph

text: in terms of three dimensions — rooted itself so deeply in the
label: Paragraph

text: human mind that no other form of perception could be imag-
label: Paragraph

text: ined. This in spite of the fact that the art of different previous
label: Paragraph

text: cultures had been two-dimensional. When earlier periods es-
label: Paragraph

text: tablished perspective as a constituent fact they were always
label: Paragraph

text: able to find new expressions for it. In the nineteenth century
label: Paragraph

text: perspective was misused. This led to its dissolution.
label: Paragraph

text: The three-dimensional space of the Renaissance is the space
label: Paragraph

text: of Euclidean geometry. But about 1830 a new sort of geometry
label: Paragraph

text: was created, one which differed from that of Euclid in employ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing more than three dimensions. Such geometries have con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinued to be developed, until now a stage has been reached
label: Paragraph

text: where mathematicians deal with figures and dimensions that
label: Paragraph

text: cannot be grasped by the imagination.
label: Paragraph

text: These considerations interest us only in so far as they affect
label: Paragraph

text: the sense of space. Like the scientist, the artist has come to
label: Paragraph

text: recognize that classic conceptions of space and volumes are
label: Paragraph

text: limited and one-sided. In particular, it has become plain that
label: Paragraph

text: the aesthetic qualities of space are not limited to its infinity
label: Paragraph

text: for sight, as in the gardens of Versailles. The essence of space
label: Paragraph

text: as it is conceived today is ils many-sidedness, the infinite poten-
label: Paragraph

text: tiality for relations within it. Exhaustive description of an
label: Paragraph

text: area from one point of reference is, accordingly, impossible; its
label: Paragraph

text: characler changes with the point from which it is viewed. In
label: Paragraph

text: order to grasp the true nature of space the observer must pro-
label: Paragraph

text: ject himself through it. The stairways in the upper levels of
label: Paragraph

text: the Eiffel Tower are among the earliest architectural cxpres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of the continuous interpenetration of outer and inner
label: Paragraph

text: space.
label: Paragraph

text: Space in modern physics is conceived of as relative to a moving
label: Paragraph

text: point of reference, not as the absolute and static entity of the
label: Paragraph

text: baroque system of Newton. And in modern art, for the first
label: Paragraph

text: time since the Renaissance, a new conception of space leads to
label: Paragraph

text: a self-conscious enlargement of our ways of perceiving space.
label: Paragraph

text: It was in cubism that this was most fully achieved.
label: Paragraph

text: The cubists did not seek to reproduce the appearance of objects
label: Paragraph

text: from one vantage point; they went round them, tried to lay
label: Paragraph

text: hold of their internal constilution. They sought to extend the
label: Paragraph

text: scale of feeling, just as contemporary science extends its de-
label: Paragraph

text: scriptions to cover new levels of material phenomena.
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism breaks with Renaissance perspective. It views objects
label: Paragraph

text: relatively: that is, from several points of view, no one of which
label: Paragraph

text: has exclusive authority. And in so dissecting objects il sees
label: Paragraph

text: them simultaneously from all sides — from above and below,
label: Paragraph

text: from inside and outside. It goes around and into its objects.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, to the three dimensions of the Renaissance which have
label: Paragraph

text: held good as constituent facls throughout so many centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: there is added a fourth one—time. The poet Guillaume
label: Paragraph

text: Apollinaire was the first to recognize and express this change,
label: Paragraph
