text: The Artistic Means
label: Title

text: * Abstract art ” is as misleading a Lerm for the different move-
label: Paragraph

text: ments which depart from the spatial approach as “ cubism ”
label: Paragraph

text: is for the beginnings of the contemporary image. It is not the
label: Paragraph

text: “ abstract,” it is not the “ cubical,’ which are significant in
label: Paragraph

text: their content. What is decisive is the invention of a new ap-
label: Paragraph

text: proach, of a new spatial representation, and the means by
label: Paragraph

text: which it is attained.
label: Paragraph

text: This new representation of space was accomplished step by
label: Paragraph

text: step, much as laboratory research gradually arrives at ils con-
label: Paragraph

text: clusions through long experimentation; and yet, as always
label: Paragraph

text: with real art and great science, the results came up out of the
label: Paragraph

text: subconscious suddenly.
label: Paragraph

text: The cubists dissect the object, try to lay hold of its inner com-
label: Paragraph

text: position. They seck to extend the scale of optical vision as
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary science extends the law of matter. Therefore
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary spatial approach has to get away from the single
label: Paragraph

text: point of reference. During the first period (shorUly before
label: Paragraph

text: 1910) this dissection of objects was accomplished, as Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Barr expresses it, by breaking up “ the surfaces of the natural
label: Paragraph

text: forms into angular facets.’’ Concentration was entirely upon
label: Paragraph

text: research into a new representation of space — thus the extreme
label: Paragraph

text: scarcity of colors in this early period. The pictures are gray-
label: Paragraph

text: toned or earthen, like the grisaille of the Renaissance or the
label: Paragraph

text: photographs of the nineteenth century. Fragments of lines
label: Caption

text: hover over the surface, often forming open angles which be-
label: Paragraph

text: come the gathering places of darker tones. These angles and
label: Paragraph

text: lines began to grow, to be extended, and suddenly out of them
label: Paragraph

text: developed one of the constituent facts of space-time represen-
label: Paragraph

text: tation — the plane (fig. 203).
label: Paragraph

text: The advancing and retreating planes of cubism, interpenetra-
label: Paragraph

text: ting, hovering, often transparent, without anything to fix them
label: Paragraph

text: in realistic position, are in fundamental contrast to the lines of
label: Paragraph

text: perspective, which converge to a single focal point.
label: Paragraph

text: Hitherto planes in themselves, without naturalistic features,
label: Paragraph

text: had lacked emotional content. Now they came to the fore as
label: Paragraph

text: an artistic means, employed in various and very different ways,
label: Paragraph

text: at times representing fragments of identifiable objects, at
label: Paragraph

text: others such things as bottles or pipes flattened out so that
label: Paragraph

text: interior and exterior could be seen simultaneously, at still
label: Paragraph

text: others completely irrational forms equivalent only to psychic
label: Paragraph

text: responses.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 1912 new clements entered; the planes were accen-
label: Paragraph

text: tualed, assumed strength and dominance, and were given an
label: Paragraph

text: additional appeal — to the tactile sense — by means of new
label: Paragraph

text: materials (scraps of paper, sawdust, glass, sand, elc.). And
label: Paragraph

text: when, though always meagerly, color was employed, it was
label: Paragraph

text: 203. PICASSO, “Still Life,”
label: Caption

text: often corrugated and roughened in order to strengthen the pig-
label: Paragraph

text: ment. In such collages fragments of newspapers, fabrics, or
label: Paragraph

text: handwriting, sometimes even single words, achieved the force
label: Paragraph

text: of new symbols.
label: Paragraph

text: The process continued, from the grayish background of the
label: Paragraph

text: first period through the collage, to the reappearance of color,
label: Paragraph

text: which gradually became stronger and more varied, until its
label: Paragraph

text: brilliant culmination in Picasso’s and Braque’s still-lifes to-
label: Paragraph

text: ward and at the beginning of the twenties. In this period, per-
label: Paragraph

text: haps cubism’s happiest, color was used in pure strength. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time curvilinear forms were introduced, taken from
label: Paragraph

text: such everyday objects as bowls and guitars, or simply invented.
label: Paragraph

text: Color no longer had the exclusive function of naturalistic
label: Paragraph

text: reproduction. Used in a spatial pattern, it was often divorced
label: Paragraph

text: from any object, asserting a right to existence in itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism originated among artists belonging to the oldest cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tures of the western world, the French and the Spanish. More
label: Paragraph

text: and more clearly it appears that this new conception of space
label: Paragraph

text: was nourished by the elements of bygone periods. Its symbols
label: Paragraph

text: were not rational, were not to be utilized directly in architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and the applied arts, but they did give force and direction
label: Paragraph

text: to artistic imagination in other fields. Following upon the first
label: Paragraph

text: efforts of the cubists, there came, as has already been said, an
label: Paragraph

text: awakening in various countries. In France appeared Le Cor-
label: Paragraph

text: busier and Ozenfant; in Russia, Malewitsch; in Hungary,
label: Paragraph

text: Moholy-Nagy; in Holland, Mondrian and van Doesburg,
label: Paragraph

text: Common to them was an attempt to rationalize cubism or, as
label: Paragraph

text: they felt was necessary, to correct its aberrations. The pro-
label: Paragraph

text: cedure was sometimes very different in different groups, but all
label: Paragraph

text: moved toward rationalization and into architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: When Ozenfant and Jeanneret (Le Corbusier) came together
label: Paragraph

text: as young painters in 1917, they called their painting Purisme
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 232). In comparison with the movements preceding it
label: Paragraph

text: (constructivism in Russia or neo-plasticism in Holland), pur-
label: Paragraph

text: ism, coming out of French soil, was the closest of all to the aim
label: Paragraph

text: of cubism and, at the same time, to architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Two years after the exhibition of the cubists in the Salon des
label: Paragraph

text: Indépendants, there appeared in Russia an abstract-art move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, fostered by Kasimir Malewitsch, which completely
label: Paragraph

text: eliminated the object. It was a flight from and a protest
label: Paragraph

text: against the naturalistic object, with painting reduced to a few
label: Paragraph

text: signs of symbolic intensity. What its paintings achieve are
label: Paragraph

text: fundamentally only pure interrelationships. Flatly extended
label: Paragraph

text: rectangles and strips float in continuous interrelation in space
label: Paragraph

text: for which there is no true human measure.
label: Paragraph

text: Interrelation, hovering, and penetration form the basis of
label: Paragraph

text: Malewitsch’s half-plastic architectural studies, which he calls
label: Paragraph

text: ‘‘architectonen.’’ These objects are not intended for a par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticular purpose but are to be understood simply as spatial
label: Paragraph

text: research. Interrelations are created between these prisms,
label: Paragraph

text: slabs, and surfaces when they penetrate or dislodge each other
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-plasticism, an expression used by the Dutch painter
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian, signifies that three-dimensional volume is reduced
label: Paragraph

text: to the new element of plasticity, the plane. Mondrian sacri-
label: Paragraph

text: fices every contact with illusionistic reproduction, going back
label: Paragraph

text: to the fundamental elements of pure color, of planes, their
label: Paragraph

text: equipoise and interrelations.
label: Paragraph

text: The small circle of young artists who gathered around Theo van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg and his periodical, Style, after 1917 progressed much
label: Paragraph

text: more radically than the French painters and architects. Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg and Mondrian sought “pure art” not in any way de-
label: Paragraph

text: flected by external motives. With them everything rests on
label: Paragraph

text: the distribution and juxtaposition of planes of pure color: blue,
label: Paragraph

text: red, yellow. To these are added black and various tones of
label: Paragraph

text: white, all being placed in a network of panels.
label: Paragraph

text: The Belgian Vantongerloo, who also belongs to this circle,
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated with the prisms, slabs, and hollows of his plastic
label: Paragraph

text: of 1918 that contemporary sculpture, like painting, was not to
label: Paragraph

text: he limited to a single point of view.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg, the moving spirit of the circle, was painter, man
label: Paragraph

text: of letters, and architect. Although he executed few buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: he cannot be omitted from the history of architecture, since,
label: Paragraph

text: like Malewitsch, he possessed the gift of recognizing the new
label: Paragraph

text: extension of the space sense and the ability to present and
label: Paragraph

text: explain it as though by laboratory experiments.
label: Paragraph

text: One of van Doesburg’s drawings in which an attempt is made
label: Paragraph

text: to present “ the elementary forms of architecture ” (lines, sur-
label: Paragraph

text: face, volume, space, time) may very well have appeared to
label: Paragraph

text: many at that time as so much disjointed nonsense (fig. 41).
label: Paragraph

text: The present-day observer, who has the advantage of being
label: Paragraph

text: able to look back upon intervening developments, has a very
label: Paragraph

text: different attitude toward these mutually penetrating flat sur-
label: Paragraph

text: faces. He sees how the enormous amount of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architecture which has since appeared acknowledges this vision
label: Paragraph

text: of space.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1923 van Doesburg, together with van Eesteren (fig. 207),
label: Paragraph

text: who later became a town planner of Amsterdam, produced a
label: Paragraph

text: house that is bolder than any other building executed during
label: Paragraph

text: the period. The breaking-up of the compact mass of the house,
label: Paragraph

text: the accessibility of the roof, the horizontal rows of windows —
label: Paragraph

text: in fact, all the features that were later to be realized in numer-
label: Paragraph

text: ous examples were indicated in it. If a collage by Georges
label: Paragraph

text: Braque (fig. 204), produced ten years earlier, consisting of
label: Paragraph

text: different papers, scraps of newspaper and fragments of planes,
label: Paragraph

text: is placed alongside a reproduction of this house, no words are
label: Paragraph

text: necessary to indicate the identity of artistic expression. An
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: THE RESEARCH INTO MOVEMENT: FUTURISM
label: Title

text: In the first decade of this century the physical sciences were
label: Paragraph

text: profoundly shaken by an inner change, the most revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps since Aristotle and the Pythagoreans. It concerned,
label: Paragraph

text: above all, the notion of time. Previously time had been re-
label: Paragraph

text: garded in one of two ways: either realistically, as something
label: Paragraph

text: going on and existing without an observer, independent of the
label: Paragraph

text: existence of other objects and without any necessary relation
label: Paragraph

text: to other phenomena; or subjectively, as something having no
label: Paragraph

text: existence apart from an observer and present only in sense
label: Paragraph

text: experience. Now came another and new way of regarding
label: Paragraph

text: time, one involving implications of the greatest significance,
label: Paragraph

text: the consequences of which cannot today be minimized or
label: Paragraph

text: ignored.
label: Paragraph

text: As was stated at the beginning of this book, it was in 1908
label: Paragraph

text: that Hermann Minkowski, the great mathematician, speaking
label: Paragraph

text: before the Naturforschenden Gesellschaft, proclaimed for the
label: Paragraph

text: first time with full certainty and precision this fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: change of conception. ‘‘ Henceforth,” he said, “ space alone
label: Paragraph

text: or time alone is doomed to fade into a mere shadow; only a
label: Paragraph

text: kind of union of both will preserve their existence.”
label: Paragraph

text: Concurrently the arts were concerned with the same problem.
label: Paragraph

text: Artistic movements with inherent constituent facts, such as
label: Paragraph

text: cubism and futurism, tried to enlarge our optical vision by
label: Paragraph

text: introducing the new unit of space-time into the language of
label: Paragraph

text: art. It is one of the indications of a common culture that the
label: Paragraph

text: same problems should have arisen simultaneously and inde-
label: Paragraph

text: pendently in both the methods of thinking and the methods of
label: Paragraph

text: feeling.
label: Paragraph

text: During the Renaissance the common artistic perception, per-
label: Paragraph

text: spective, was expressed by one group of artists primarily
label: Paragraph

text: through lines, and by another primarily through colors. So in
label: Paragraph

text: our own day the common background of space-time has been
label: Paragraph

text: explored by the cubists through spatial representation and by
label: Paragraph

text: the futurists through research into movement.
label: Paragraph

text: For Jakob Burckhardt there reigned in Italy ‘the quiet of the
label: Paragraph

text: tomb.” The futurists were a reaction against this quietness;
label: Paragraph

text: they felt ashamed that Italy had become simply a refuge for
label: Paragraph

text: those seeking to escape from the demands and realities of the
label: Paragraph

text: present. They called upon art to come forth from the twilit
label: Paragraph

text: caves of the muscums, to assert itself in the fullness of modern
label: Paragraph

text: thought and feeling, to speak out in authentic Lerms of the
label: Paragraph

text: moment. Life was their cry — explosive life, movement, ac-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, heroism — in every phase of human life, in polities, in
label: Paragraph

text: war, in art: the discovery of new beauties and a new sensibility
label: Title

text: through the forces of our period. Not without right did they
label: Paragraph

text: claim to be “ the first Italian youth in centuries.”’ ?
label: Paragraph

text: So, from the beginning, they plunged into the full struggle,
label: Paragraph

text: carried their cause militantly to the public. The poet Mari-
label: Paragraph

text: netti, whose apartment in Rome even to this day bears
label: Paragraph

text: the escutcheon of the “Movimento futurista,” proclaimed in
label: Paragraph

text: the Parisian Figaro of February 20, 1909, “We affirm that the
label: Paragraph

text: splendor of the world has been enriched by a new beauty:
label: Paragraph

text: the beauty of speed.’’ And later, in 1912, in the ‘Second
label: Paragraph

text: Technical Manifesto of Futurist Painting,” the futurists de-
label: Paragraph

text: veloped their principal discovery, that “objects in motion
label: Paragraph

text: multiply and distort themselves, just as do vibrations, which
label: Paragraph

text: indeed they are, in passing through space.” The most exciting
label: Paragraph

text: of their paintings realize this artistic principle.
label: Paragraph

text: The productions of futurist painting, sculpture, and architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture are based on the representation of movement and its corre-
label: Paragraph

text: lates: interpenetration and simultaneity. One of the futur-
label: Paragraph

text: ists’ best minds and without any doubt their best sculptor,
label: Paragraph

text: Umberto Boccioni, who died much too early, in 1916, has most
label: Paragraph

text: clearly defined their purposes. In an effort to penetrate more
label: Paragraph

text: deeply into the very essence of painting, he sought terms for his
label: Paragraph

text: art, terms which, now obscurely felt, now shining clear and im-
label: Paragraph

text: mediate in his increasing creative experience, anticipated those
label: Paragraph

text: that later appeared in the atomic theory. ‘‘We should start,”
label: Paragraph

text: he said, “from the central nucleus of the object wanting to
label: Paragraph

text: create itself, in order to discover those new forms which con-
label: Paragraph

text: nect the object invisibly with the infinite of the apparent
label: Paragraph

text: plasticily and the infinite of the inner plasticity.”
label: Paragraph

text: PAINTING TODAY
label: Title

text: Since the first decade of this century the research into space has
label: Paragraph

text: broadened through various successive stages, never losing, how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, its original and primary concern with the new conception.
label: Paragraph

text: What it had arrived at in the late thirlies may be compre-
label: Paragraph

text: hended in a single painting which in itself sums up the entire
label: Paragraph

text: experience of three decades — the “Guernica” of Picasso. In
label: Paragraph

text: it are embodied the principle of simultaneity, the penetration
label: Paragraph

text: of inner and outer space, the working with curved planes and
label: Paragraph

text: different textures.’ Nevertheless, this mural of the Spanish war
label: Paragraph

text: seems to be the first real historical painting since the beginning
label: Paragraph

text: of the Renaissance and the work of Paolo Uccello. It is the
label: Paragraph

text: tragedy of a country distilled to its full strength by an artist
label: Paragraph

text: able to transmute physical suffering and destruction into
label: Paragraph

text: powerful symbols — a mother with her dead child, a woman
label: Paragraph

text: falling in a burning house, a spear-transfixed horse, fragments
label: Caption

text: of a mutilated warrior, one severed hand clutching a broken
label: Paragraph

text: sword, all triumphantly surveyed by a great bull and lit by a
label: Paragraph

text: lamp held in an outstretched hand. Above the carnage shines
label: Paragraph

text: “the radiant eye of day with the electric bulb of night for a
label: Paragraph

text: pupil.”
label: Paragraph

text: In the course of its composition, the picture went through many
label: Paragraph

text: variations and preliminary studies, but one detail remained un-
label: Paragraph

text: changed almost from the beginning — the rush of flight con-
label: Paragraph

text: densed into a symbol of two elongated human heads with hair
label: Paragraph

text: streaming back, chin and neck in one sweeping line, the faces
label: Paragraph

text: as if enclosed in spherical triangles (fig. 212). How charged
label: Paragraph

text: with inner truth this symbol of Picasso’s is has recently been
label: Paragraph

text: revealed by the stroboscope of Edgerton, which is able photo-
label: Paragraph

text: graphically to disintegrate a movement into single parts which
label: Paragraph

text: the human eye is incapable of grasping. A study of one of
label: Paragraph

text: these stroboscopic photographs (fig. 211) makes clear how
label: Paragraph

text: closely connected are the realizations of the creative artist and
label: Paragraph

text: those of the scientist. Out of the unknown, an artist like
label: Paragraph

text: Picasso can produce intuitively symbols for a reality which, as in
label: Paragraph

text: In the early days of reinforced concrete the same methods of
label: Paragraph

text: construction were used as were employed with timber and iron.
label: Paragraph

text: Timber, being the trunks of trees, has length, just as iron has
label: Paragraph

text: when rolled into long girders. One dimension always domi-
label: Paragraph

text: nates, which is the one that transmils the load. As Maillart
label: Paragraph

text: himself puts it: * The engineer was so accustomed to using those
label: Paragraph

text: basic materials which provide only one-dimensional support
label: Paragraph

text: that they became second nature to him, and restrained him
label: Paragraph

text: from exploiting other possibilities. This was the state of affairs
label: Paragraph

text: when reinforced concrete was introduced, and at first no
label: Paragraph

text: change ensued.”
label: Paragraph

text: Maillart was a pupil of Hennebique;’ and Hennebique’s rein-
label: Paragraph

text: forced concrete structures had beams and columns like timber-
label: Paragraph

text: framed buildings. Following the model of timber construction,
label: Paragraph

text: his beams reached from wall to wall and from column to col-
label: Paragraph

text: umn, the roof stretching across them in the form of a flat, inert
label: Paragraph

text: slab. This was the point where Maillart began his life’s work.
label: Paragraph

text: Like all great constructors, he has consistently followed a single
label: Paragraph

text: line of thought which he has progressively developed and ex-
label: Paragraph

text: panded in the course of his career.
label: Paragraph

text: In designing a bridge Maillart began by eliminating ali that
label: Paragraph

text: was nonfunctional; thus everything that remained was an im-
label: Paragraph

text: mediate part of its structure. He did this by improving the
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete slab until he had turned it mto a new
label: Paragraph

text: structural element. What Maillart has achieved since then is
label: Paragraph

text: based on one idea: that it is possible to reinforce a flat or
label: Paragraph

text: curved concrete slab in such a manner as to dispense with the
label: Paragraph

text: need for beams in flooring or solid arches in bridges. It is very
label: Paragraph

text: difficult to determine the forces present in slabs of this nature
label: Paragraph

text: by calculation alone. To obtain positive results entailed a
label: Paragraph

text: complicated process which cannot be entered into here, except
label: Paragraph

text: to say that it was based partly on calculation and partly on
label: Paragraph

text: experiment.

label: Title

text: MENT
label: Title

text: Germany in the Nineteenth Century
label: Title

text: Manual production methods are deeply rooted in the German
label: Paragraph

text: temperament. Industrial liberty, proclaimed in France in
label: Paragraph

text: 1791, was not adopted in Prussia until 1846. It did not come
label: Paragraph

text: to the south of Germany until 1862. There was a great crisis
label: Paragraph

text: in England during the second decade of the nincteenth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury as a consequence of the change from hand to mechanized
label: Paragraph

text: production. In France in 1835 hand weavers were declared to
label: Paragraph

text: be “in the last spasms of agony.’ Gustav Schmoller, the
label: Paragraph

text: economist, notes that this period in Germany witnessed an
label: Paragraph

text: increase in the percentage of manual workers and a marked
label: Paragraph

text: trend toward production by small artisans.
label: Paragraph

text: During the nineteenth century the number of power spindles
label: Paragraph

text: in a country was an accurate index of its degree of industrializa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. In the year 1865 there was one such spindle in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: to three in France and eight in England. Other branches of
label: Paragraph

text: industry showed parallel stages of development, including the
label: Paragraph

text: steamship and the railroad, which, as Sombart says, entered
label: Paragraph

text: Germany “ on the crutches of English industry.”
label: Paragraph

text: American industry was only in the first stages of its develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ment in the first half of the nineteenth century. But, as later
label: Paragraph

text: developments indicate, there was a fundamental difference
label: Paragraph

text: between the two countries. From the start, the American
label: Paragraph

text: spirit was orientated toward mechanized production.
label: Paragraph

text: But around 1870 a rapid transformation sets in and steadily
label: Paragraph

text: gains speed. Germany, the country of the hand worker and the
label: Paragraph

text: farmer, drives on with the aim of becoming not only an indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trialized state but the leader of the industrial age.
label: Paragraph

text: This early indifference to the machine and the factory followed
label: Paragraph

text: by a headlong acceptance had serious human and psychological
label: Paragraph

text: consequences. The deep uncertainty that prevailed at this
label: Paragraph

text: period in Germany is reflected in its architecture. Other coun-
label: Paragraph

text: tries were expanding, but their architecture shows nothing like
label: Paragraph

text: so complete a loss of inner equilibrium and confusion with
label: Paragraph

text: regard to fundamental principles as was seen in Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: There was nothing that resembled William Morris’ work in
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius entered upon his career in the Germany of the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The first large commission which Gropius received after open-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: excellence’? — take form. The moment he set to work for
label: Paragraph

text: himself he dropped his master’s classical solemnity entirely
label: Paragraph

text: and made the new aims of architecture clearly apparent. In
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: yalues.!® The break between thinking and feeling which had
label: Paragraph

text: been the bone-sickness of European architecture was healed.

text: Post-War Germany and the Bauhaus
label: Title

text: All the vigorous efforts of the decade before the war ended in
label: Paragraph

text: disillusionment. The arts and crafls movement was seen to
label: Paragraph

text: have worked itself out. It had, indeed, done much to climi-
label: Paragraph

text: nate fashions that were carry-overs from the previous period,
label: Paragraph

text: but improvements in furniture and reforms in lhousehold taste
label: Title

text: opened up no real outlet for continued fulure development.
label: Paragraph

text: In the German movement, architecture was swallowed up by
label: Paragraph

text: the applied arts. This in ilself shows that the movement pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced reforms but no new posilive conceptions. since without
label: Paragraph

text: a new conception there can be no new archilecture. Solutions
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Fagus works (1911-14) were isolated exceptions
label: Paragraph

text: that could not make their influence felt at the moment.
label: Paragraph

text: A state of widespread uncertainty once more prevailed. This
label: Paragraph

text: uncertainty was, so to speak, the working-capital — not the
label: Paragraph

text: object of attack — of the expressionist movement. German
label: Caption

text: expressionism had its beginnings previous lo the war, con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinued to develop while the war lasted, and reached its height
label: Paragraph

text: in the years immediately after the war. The movement elo-
label: Paragraph

text: quently states the grievances of mishandled humanity and
label: Paragraph

text: indicts a tragic situation. But there is a fundamental dif-

text: The expressionist influence could not be a healthy one or per-

text: This was the situation into which the Bauhaus came at its

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Gropius was instinctively aware of the inadequacy of expres
label: Paragraph

text: sionism and of the need to escape from it. The war had left

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: He gave the preliminary course to the young Swiss painter,
label: Paragraph

text: Johannes Itten. Itten, while teaching in Vienna, had devel-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the sense of color, and the sense of space and composition.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: through the Bauhaus period. The German sculptor Gerhard
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: with Itten at the beginning. Feininger was one of the few ex-
label: Paragraph

text: pressionists interested in problems of space.

text: By 1926 a new generation had set to work in archilecture.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The Bauhaus complex is an arrangement of cubes, one jux-
label: Paragraph

text: taposed against another — cubes differing in size, material,
label: Paragraph

text: and location. The aim is not to anchor them to the ground but
label: Paragraph

text: to have them float or hover upon the site. This is the reason
label: Paragraph

text: for the winglike connecting bridges and the liberal use of glass,
label: Paragraph

text: The glass was called in for its dematerializing quality; the
label: Paragraph

text: previous generation had used it either for practical purposes or
label: Paragraph

text: (in private houses) had stained or painted it.
label: Paragraph

text: These cubes are juxtaposed and interrelated. Indeed, they
label: Paragraph

text: interpenetrate each other so subtly and intimately that the
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries of the various volumes cannot be sharply picked
label: Paragraph

text: out. The views from the air show how thoroughly each is
label: Paragraph

text: blended into a unified composition. The eye cannot sum up
label: Paragraph

text: this complex at one view; it is necessary to go around it on all
label: Paragraph

text: sides, to see it from above as well as from below. This means
label: Paragraph

text: new dimensions for the artistic imagination, an unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: many-sidedness.
label: Paragraph

text: The ground plan lacks all tendency to contract inward upon
label: Paragraph

text: itself; it expands, on the contrary, and reaches out over the
label: Paragraph

text: ground. In outline it resembles one of those fireworks called
label: Paragraph

text: “pinwhecls,” with three hooked arms extending from a
label: Paragraph

text: center (fig. 228). The impression one receives from it is similar
label: Paragraph

text: to that produced by the glassed staircase in Gropius’ exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion building of 1914: it suggests a movement in space that
label: Paragraph

text: has been seized and held.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bauhaus was the only large building of its date which was
label: Paragraph

text: so complete a crystallization of the new space conception. Its
label: Paragraph

text: appearance is in a way testimony to the irrational course of
label: Paragraph

text: history. Germany in the second half of the nineteenth century
label: Paragraph

text: showed a greater loss of architectonic honesty than any
label: Paragraph

text: other country. Bul il was in this very country, after less Lhan
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: accomplishment in architecture.

text: form. They appear at their purest, perhaps, in his Villa

label: Caption

text: All Le Corbusier’s houses attack the same problem. He is
label: Paragraph

text: always endeavoring to open up the house, to create new possi-
label: Paragraph

text: bilities for connections between its interior and exterior and
label: Paragraph

text: within the interior itsclf. We want rooms which can be
label: Paragraph

text: thrown open or enclosed at will, rooms whese outer partitions
label: Paragraph

text: fall away when we wish. Briefly, it is a question of achieving
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings of a sort which, up to the present, have been beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the reach of conception and execution alike. The armature
label: Paragraph

text: construction is here in secret alliance with our half-realized
label: Paragraph

text: desires; it anticipates them, in fact.
label: Paragraph

text: Previously to this, Le Corbusier's houses had been built on
label: Paragraph

text: rather cramped plots, in more or less close proximity to their
label: Paragraph

text: neighbors. The site of the Savoie house, on the contrary, was
label: Paragraph

text: completely isolated (fig. 234).
label: Paragraph

text: The problem involved here was one which affects every man
label: Paragraph

text: when he leaves his work and seeks to regain contact with
label: Paragraph

text: nature, with growing things, the countryside, and the sky.
label: Paragraph

text: This attempt to renew our connections with nature raises the
label: Paragraph

text: same fundamental questions wherever we build, by the sea-
label: Paragraph

text: shore, in the mountains, or — as in this case — on the undu-
label: Paragraph

text: lating expanses of the Seine valley just outside Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: At one period in his development Frank Lloyd Wright used to
label: Paragraph

text: employ the smallest crevices in the rocks to help bind his
label: Paragraph

text: houses still more closely to the earth. In the Savoie house Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier does exactly the opposite. The city-dweller for whom
label: Paragraph

text: it was designed wanted to look out over the countryside rather
label: Paragraph

text: than to be set down among trees and shrubbery. He wanted to
label: Paragraph

text: enjoy the view, the breezes, and the sun—to experience that un-
label: Paragraph

text: hurricd natural freedom which his work deprived him of. This is
label: Paragraph

text: another instance of two eternally opposed responses to nature:
label: Paragraph

text: a contemporary reflection of the difference between the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: temple, sharply outlined against its background, and the medie-
label: Paragraph

text: yal town, attached like a plant to the site on which it stands.
label: Paragraph

text: This house is a cube elevated on pillars. The cube part is not

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the whole interior instead of mercly skimming the outer wall.

text: were — not only in the interior rooms but also on the terrace,

text: ground to the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: It is impossible to comprehend the Savoie house by a view
label: Paragraph

text: from a single point; quite literally, it is a construction in space-
label: Paragraph

text: time. The body of the house has been hollowed out in every

label: Paragraph

text: each other inextricably.
label: Paragraph

text: Borromini had been on the verge of achieving the interpenetra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of inner and outer space in some of his late baroque
label: Paragraph

text: churches. This interpenetration was first realized in our period,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: sible to achieve it in a dwelling. This possibility was latent
label: Paragraph

text: in the skeleton system of construction, but the skeleton had to
label: Paragraph

text: be used as Le Corbusier uses it: in the service of a new concep-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of space. That is what he means when he defines architec-
label: Paragraph

text: The League of Nations Competition, 1927: Contemporary Archi-
label: Title

text: teclure Comes to the Front
label: Title

text: The 1927 international competition for the League of Nations
label: Title

text: Palace at Geneva is one of the most illuminating episodes in
label: Paragraph

text: the history of contemporary architecture. For the first time
label: Paragraph

text: present-day architects challenged the routine of the Academy
label: Paragraph

text: ina field which it had dominated for generations, the design of
label: Paragraph

text: monumentally impressive state buildings. The Academy won
label: Paragraph

text: this particular engagement, but its victory injured the prestige
label: Paragraph

text: of its methods.
label: Paragraph

text: The conventional routines showed themselves incapable of
label: Paragraph

text: producing architectonic solutions to problems of modern
label: Paragraph

text: organization. The proof of that helplessness did much to
label: Paragraph

text: break down popular resistance to modern treatments.
label: Paragraph

text: It was plain from the start that, among the 337 projects sub-
label: Paragraph

text: mitted, one — the work of Le Corbusier and Pierre Jcanneret
label: Paragraph

text: -— was peculiarly important and significant. Later develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ments verified this first judgment.
label: Paragraph

text: What made it important? It unexpectedly forced high officials
label: Paragraph

text: from everywhere in Europe to consider seriously a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture which they had always dismissed as aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: trifling. For decades there had been an established style for
label: Paragraph

text: the stately official building — an international style that
label: Paragraph

text: hardly varied from country to country. Custom had made its
label: Paragraph

text: validity seem guaranteed for all time, and the official element
label: Paragraph

text: automatically turned to it when the matter of their Geneva
label: Paragraph

text: setting came up. The scheme that came to the forefront, how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, shockingly disregarded the stylistic approach in order to
label: Paragraph

text: tackle, quite openly, the specific problems which the building
label: Paragraph

text: raised.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea of a league of nations is one which we encounter time
label: Paragraph

text: and again in history. Its realization, however — the actual
label: Paragraph

text: establishment of a neutral center where representatives of
label: Paragraph

text: every country might meet to maintain the equilibrium of the
label: Paragraph

text: world — was a completely new thing and brought a highly
label: Paragraph

text: complex institution into being. [ts varied functions required a
label: Paragraph

text: division of its headquarters into three main parts: a secretariat,
label: Paragraph

text: where the daily work of its administration could be carried on;
label: Paragraph

text: amecting place for committees of various sorts whose sessions
label: Paragraph

text: occurred intermittently (the Conseil and the Grandes Commis.
label: Paragraph

text: sions); and a hall for the yearly sitting of the Assemblée
label: Paragraph

text: generale. Besides this, a great library had to be incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: into the whole complex.
label: Paragraph

text: The outstanding fact about the scheme submitted by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier and Jeanneret * is that they found the most com-
label: Paragraph

text: pact and best-conceived solution to these needs (fig. 238).**

text: The Undulating Wall
label: Title

text: One of the few buildings in which Aalto could freely express
label: Paragraph

text: himself was the Viipuri Library, built with difficulty between
label: Paragraph

text: 1927 and 1934. It was damaged in the first Russo-Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: war and almost razed to the ground in the following conflict.
label: Paragraph

text: It consisted of the library proper, which had carefully con-
label: Paragraph

text: structed circular overhead lights, and an unusually shaped
label: Paragraph

text: lecture hall with a spacious connecting vestibule.’
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s treatment of the undulating wooden ceiling of the
label: Paragraph

text: lecture hall is of great historical importance. The architect
label: Paragraph

text: hall.
label: Paragraph

text: today appears nowhere so hesitant as in the region of the
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling, above the reach of everyday functions. Ilere, to a
label: Caption

text: large extent, is a freedom of opportunity to excite the plastic
label: Paragraph

text: imagination of an artist. The solution of the problem of
label: Paragraph

text: spanning space has always been an indication of the crealive-
label: Paragraph

text: ness of a period.
label: Paragraph

text: *For a complete description see Alfred Roth, The New Architecture (Zurich, 1940),
label: Caption

text: Alvar Aalto is, like Le Corbusier, one of the few architects
label: Paragraph

text: who in our times has tried anew to attack the vaulting problem
label: Paragraph

text: in a way peculiar to this period.* In the intimate hall of the
label: Caption

text: Viipuri Library the irrational curves of the ceiling glide
label: Title

text: through space like the serpentine lines of a Miro painting
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 2455). From the floor behind the speaker, narrow strips
label: Caption

text: of redwood sweep upward, curving irrationally along the glass
label: Paragraph

text: wall. Of course, the architect himself can prove, with metic-
label: Paragraph

text: ulous acoustic diagrams, that the undulating form he gave the
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling enables sound to reach the human ear more perfectly.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, therefore, scientific reasoning and artistic imagination
label: Paragraph

text: have merged to free architecture from that rigidity which is
label: Paragraph

text: today an ever present menace.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto treated the walls of his Finnish Pavilion with even
label: Paragraph

text: greater freedom. This was without doubt the most daring
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: an inclined wooden screen three stories high embraces the
label: Paragraph

text: interior space in a freely drawn curve. The screen consists of
label: Paragraph

text: three sections,*each cantilevered over the other; at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time the whole structure leans forward, intensifying thereby
label: Paragraph

text: the impression of continuous movement. A series of vertical
label: Paragraph

text: ribs and the rhythm of their changing shadows animate the
label: Paragraph

text: surface of the huge screen (fig. 245k).
label: Caption

text: Each detail has a well-reasoned explanation. In the tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nique of poster display, the undulating surface provides more
label: Paragraph

text: space for large photographs; the forward tilting brings the
label: Paragraph

text: uppermost pictures closer to the angle of vision; the series of
label: Paragraph

text: vertical ribs thrust the photographs forward; the cantilever of
label: Paragraph

text: the upper stories, which so intensifies the impression of hov-
label: Paragraph

text: ering movement, provides room for a concentrated display
label: Paragraph

text: of objects.
label: Paragraph

text: The outstanding feature is the new modeling of inner space
label: Paragraph

text: that is involved in this experiment, which to many still ap-
label: Paragraph

text: Organic Town Planning
label: Title

text: Town planning is only another term for integration. In this
label: Paragraph

text: heyday of narrow-minded specialization, nothing is more dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ficult than to conceive or to build up a whole from a number
label: Paragraph

text: of different parts.
label: Paragraph

text: The ability to integrate is normally developed towards the end
label: Paragraph

text: of a period, when it is at its cultural peak. This is particularly
label: Paragraph

text: true in relation to town planning.
label: Paragraph

text: We are now at the beginning of a period; yet, it is already
label: Paragraph

text: necessary for us to possess those qualities that normally de-
label: Paragraph

text: velop much later. As far as I know, this situation is unique.
label: Paragraph

text: But it exists, and we must act accordingly. We are confronted
label: Paragraph

text: here and now with the necessity of finding a solution to the
label: Paragraph

text: complex problems of the city, although specialists are still
label: Paragraph

text: sharply discussing what kind of city it should be, and al-
label: Paragraph

text: though we ourselves are perhaps not even quite sure what-a
label: Paragraph

text: town hall should look like. Let us not forget the present sit-
label: Paragraph

text: uation: that our imagination begins to freeze as soon as
label: Paragraph

text: problems of integration are involved.
label: Paragraph

text: What is Aalto’s contribution in the field of town planning?
label: Paragraph

text: We can only touch on a few points here. The same qualities
label: Paragraph

text: which enliven his buildings are even more obvious in his plan-
label: Paragraph

text: ping schemes. With the same freedom that he has employed
label: Paragraph

text: to loosen up the structure of walls and ceilings, he loosens up
label: Paragraph

text: the rigid framework of the human settlement. Rows of
label: Paragraph

text: houses scattered in all directions seem to have been strewn
label: Paragraph

text: by the wind, and yet they are held together by an invisible
label: Paragraph

text: force, like filings in a magnetic field.
label: Paragraph

text: In the layout of Sunila, 1937-39 (fig. 245t), Alvar Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: approach to town planning is already manifest. ‘The whole
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of his later schemes will reflect the same principles.
label: Paragraph

text: These may be briefly described as establishing an equipoise
label: Paragraph

text: between the primary demands for a human environment: an
label: Paragraph

text: equipoise between the living area, the center of production,
label: Paragraph

text: and nature.
label: Paragraph

text: To secure the right of the individual to privacy, to a simple
label: Paragraph

text: community life, and to the most intimate contact with the
label: Paragraph

text: earth is today the preoccupation of every planner. This aim
label: Paragraph

text: is no longer original. Today these demands have become a
label: Paragraph

text: matter of course. What is still lacking is their realization.
label: Paragraph

text: We will not easily find, as early as 1937, many achievements
label: Paragraph

text: like Sunila, where both the production area and the living
label: Paragraph

text: area have been conceived in such a way that each has been
label: Paragraph

text: given its necessary rights without disturbing the other. The
label: Paragraph

text: grasp of a town planner can be felt in the layout of one-family
label: Paragraph

text: houses upon the narrowest strip of the available Jand; in the
label: Paragraph

text: grouping of row houses freely in the forest; in the slight varia-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of the engineers’ row houses, which lie nearer to the
label: Paragraph

text: waterfront and are arranged in a slight curve, to ensure the
label: Paragraph

text: utmost privacy for each dwelling. It goes without saying that
label: Paragraph

text: the necessary social facilities (especially several saunas —
label: Paragraph

text: communal bathing houses) are located at strategic intervals.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s integrated approach enables him to have the struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural completion of the whole cornnmunity in his mind, even
label: Paragraph

text: when he begins with only the first few cells. Together with
label: Paragraph

text: other architects, he has been working, since 194-4, on the so-
label: Paragraph

text: lution of the large-scale problem of the reconstruction of
label: Paragraph

text: Furniture in Standard Units
label: Title

text: In Alvar Aalto’s opinion, a house is not only a far more com-
label: Paragraph

text: plicated organ than an automobile; there is also a real dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ference between an object which one may live in for a gen-
label: Paragraph

text: eration and a vehicle of transport which one may conveniently
label: Paragraph

text: exchange every second season. Furthermore, no two sites are
label: Paragraph

text: the same. Above all, the house reaches too far into the
label: Paragraph

text: psychic to admit of total mass fabrication.
label: Paragraph

text: Only elements of it should be standardized: doors, windows.
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical equipment, and constructional members, whether
label: Paragraph

text: they consist of skeleton or panel. The important matter is
label: Paragraph

text: that architectural freedom should be preserved. The stan-
label: Paragraph

text: dardized elements should awaken, not destroy, architectural
label: Paragraph

text: vision.

label: Paragraph

text: made parts. The comparison can be taken no further, how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever. The type house, the prefabricated house. kills the

text: phantasy of the architect and administers a deathblow to
label: Paragraph

text: organic town planning. But furniture is predestined to be

text: The Human Side
label: Title

text: One cannot speak about Aalto the architect without speaking
label: Paragraph

text: about Aalto the man. People are at least as important to him
label: Paragraph

text: as architecture. Aalto is interested in every human being, in
label: Paragraph

text: each of their particular desires and experiences, no matter
label: Paragraph

text: where they come from or to what social class they belong. He
label: Paragraph

text: draws incentive and stimulation from contact with men of
label: Paragraph

text: varied callings, much as James Joyce did. Indeed, Aalto can-
label: Paragraph

text: not set foot outside his door without becoming involved in
label: Paragraph

text: some human episode. He approaches people directly and
label: Paragraph

text: without inhibitions, in the same way that he approaches the
label: Paragraph

text: organic material wood.
label: Paragraph

text: When Aalto first appeared, unknown to the rest of us, within
label: Paragraph

text: the circle of the newly formed CIAM, in Frankfurt in 1929,
label: Paragraph

text: he did not talk about his buildings but instead told us of a
label: Paragraph

text: delicate adventure that had befallen him at nine o’clock that
label: Paragraph

text: morning, on his way from the station to the hotel. In 1933,
label: Paragraph

text: when he was traveling from Finland to the Athens Congress
label: Paragraph

text: by plane, rail, and automobile, to take part in the formulation
label: Paragraph

text: of the Charte d’Athénes, the Jong conversations that he had
label: Paragraph

text: on his journey were of the greatest interest to him. Travel-
label: Paragraph

text: ing with him was an elderly woman in a plaster cast —a
label: Paragraph

text: grandmother, as he told us — whom he attended and assisted
label: Paragraph

text: from train to train.
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto came to America for the first time in 1939 to build the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish Pavilion at the New York World’s Fair. His English
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary was far from extensive, yet he lectured to the
label: Paragraph

text: pampered public of the Museum of Modern Art in New York.
label: Caption

text: The way that he stood there, the way in which he was able
label: Paragraph

text: to express what he had to say with his fragmentary vocab-
label: Paragraph

text: ulary and a few “‘okay’’s, captivated his audience from the
label: Paragraph

text: start.

text: THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONTEMPORARY
label: Title

text: ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: It would be a complete misunderstanding to suppose that con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary architecture has been evolved by a few isolated
label: Paragraph

text: geniuses. Vigorous artists, creative spirits strong enough to
label: Paragraph

text: push beyond the dominant conventions — without these, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, nothing could have been achieved. But contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is no longer dependent upon a few individuals; it
label: Paragraph

text: has its roots deep in the life of our day. It grows more and
label: Paragraph

text: more anonymous; innumerable workers in every part of the
label: Paragraph

text: world contribute to its nourishment and progress.
label: Paragraph

text: The emphasis falls increasingly upon solutions, rather than
label: Paragraph

text: upon the individual architect. This is the difference between
label: Paragraph

text: the generation of the pioneers and the generation that has come
label: Title

text: afler them. Individual crealive work remains necessary, but
label: Paragraph

text: the complicated problems which have to be solved (along with
label: Paragraph

text: a growing unity of expression) are leading to more and more
label: Paragraph

text: collaborative work. Architects are collaborating not only
label: Paragraph

text: wilh other architects but also with specialists of every de-
label: Paragraph

text: scription — landscape gardeners, physicians, statisticians, and
label: Paragraph

text: many others.
label: Paragraph

text: This inspired a new collectivity and united the leading archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects of many countries in the CIAM (the Congrés interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tionaux d’architecture moderne)... The CIAM sets itself to
label: Paragraph

text: analyze and work out problems which no solitary worker could
label: Paragraph

text: handle. It dealt first with the problem of dwellings for the
label: Paragraph

text: lower income classes (Frankfort, in 1929), went on to the
label: Paragraph

text: treatment of block units (Brussels, 1930), and then to town
label: Paragraph

text: planning (Athens, 1933).
label: Paragraph

text: The principles governing the attack upon these problems were
label: Paragraph

text: always the same. To gain a universal insight into actual facts
label: Paragraph

text: and conditions, groups in various countries carried out careful
label: Paragraph

text: analyses. The same methods were used by each group, the
label: Paragraph

text: same modes of representation, the same scale. Low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: * June 1928, at the instigation of Mme Héléne de Mandrot de la Sarraz, who offered
label: Paragraph

text: the association every possible help and made available the old Chateau de la Sarraz for
label: Paragraph

text: its first meeting.
label: Paragraph

text: housing, block units, and town layouts were studied in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: and elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture has ceased to be the concern of passive and busi-
label: Paragraph

text: nesslike specialists who build precisely what their clients bar-
label: Paragraph

text: gain for. Architecture has cast off this passivity; it has gained
label: Paragraph

text: the courage to deal actively with life, to help mold it. It starts
label: Paragraph

text: with intimately vital questions, inquiring into the needs of
label: Paragraph

text: the child, the woman, and the man. It asks, “What kind of
label: Paragraph

text: life are you leading? Are we responsible for the conditions you
label: Paragraph

text: have to put up with? How must we plan — not just in the
label: Paragraph

text: case of houses, but clear through to regional areas — so that
label: Paragraph

text: you may have a life worthy of the name? ”
label: Paragraph

text: When we go to the bottom of questions like these, we see that
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary architecture takes its start in a moral problem.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture has emerged from the realm of narrow specializa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to plunge into the realities of ordinary life. And by taking
label: Paragraph

text: off his specialist’s blinders, the architect has greatly extended
label: Paragraph

text: his influence. Architecture is a highly complex activity; it
label: Paragraph

text: works in the boundary area halfway between the regions of
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic feeling and practical doing. But this is just the reason
label: Paragraph

text: why we look to it to give us the kind of surroundings that will
label: Paragraph

text: express the life of our period.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern painters have enlarged our visual experience by work-
label: Paragraph

text: ing with relations between objects which we had never taken
label: Paragraph

text: cognizance of in our ordinary, half-automatic seeing. Con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary architects have been just as willing to anticipate
label: Paragraph

text: public understanding. They too have refused to wait until
label: Paragraph

text: they could be sure of universal approbation for their work.
label: Paragraph

text: Following an impulse which was half ethical, half artistic,
label: Paragraph

text: they have sought to provide our life with its corresponding
label: Paragraph

text: shell or framework. And where contemporary architecture
label: Paragraph

text: has been allowed to provide a new setting for contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: life, this new setting has acted in its turn upon the life from
label: Paragraph

text: which it springs. The new atmosphere has led to change and
label: Paragraph

text: development in the conceptions of the people who live in it.
label: Paragraph

text: This is understandable enough if we regard architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Aragon does painting: as a language, and not as a mere
label: Paragraph

text: matter of taste.
label: Paragraph

text: In the past (and to some extent even now) really creative art
label: Paragraph

text: has met with resistance from a public whose conceptual de-
label: Paragraph

text: yelopment had outdistanced its emotional growth. The fight
label: Paragraph

text: which contemporary architecture in Europe had to wage to
label: Paragraph

text: establish itself was due to just this gap between thinking and
label: Paragraph

text: feeling. That fight would never have succeeded if architecture
label: Paragraph

text: had waited for other branches of knowledge to arrive at a
label: Paragraph

text: coordinated and universal outlook. Builders, sociologists,
label: Paragraph

text: economists, political theorists — none of these have as yet
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled all their aims. Meanwhile the architects have
label: Paragraph

text: worked with whatever means were at hand — sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: yery primitive ones, with which completely satisfactory
label: Paragraph

text: solutions were impossible — to establish the contours of a
label: Paragraph

text: new kind of life.
label: Paragraph

text: Many different countries have contributed to the development
label: Paragraph

text: which we have been discussing. It would be interesting to
label: Paragraph

text: observe the spread of the new movements, through Holland,
label: Paragraph

text: France, Germany, Sweden, England, and elsewhere; to see
label: Paragraph

text: what direction was taken in each of these countries and the
label: Paragraph

text: special dangers which each involves; to note the influence of
label: Paragraph

text: environment and tradition upon the solution of architectural
label: Title

text: problems. Such local differences have a more than superficial
label: Paragraph

text: importance. Those countries which accepted contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as a kind of universal coinage — a collection of
label: Paragraph

text: particular shapes which retained their full value wherever they
label: Paragraph

text: were transplanted — invited architectural bankruptcy. Mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern architecture is something more than a universally appli-
label: Paragraph

text: cable means of decoration. It is too much the product of our
label: Paragraph

text: whole period not to exhibit some universal tendencies, but, on
label: Paragraph

text: the other hand, it is too much concerned with problems of
label: Paragraph

text: actual living to ignore local differences in needs, customs, and
label: Paragraph

text: materials. Finland, under the leadership of Alvar Aalto, has
label: Paragraph

text: shown how contributions can be made to architecture univer-
label: Paragraph

text: sally through solutions adapted to the specific conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: their native setting.
label: Paragraph

text: We must break off here, however, in spite of the interest and
label: Paragraph

text: importance of these branches of the main movement. As
label: Paragraph

text: always, our purpose is to follow developments only to the
label: Paragraph

text: point where full consciousness of their import and direction
label: Paragraph

text: has been reached. Today the most urgent and unsettled prob-
label: Paragraph

text: lems arise in another field, in that of town planning. To gain
label: Paragraph

text: some insight into these problems, to become aware of whal lies
label: Paragraph

text: behind present conditions, to see if there is any escape from
label: Paragraph

text: the desolate city of our times: these are things we cannot avoid
label: Paragraph

text: attempting.

text: CITY PLANNING
label: Title

text: IN THE NINETEENTH CENTURY
label: Title

text: Early Nineleenth Century
label: Title

text: Once again we must turn back to the nineteenth century. We
label: Paragraph

text: can appreciate what is required in the sphere of town planning
label: Paragraph

text: today only if we understand how the present situation has come
label: Paragraph

text: about.
label: Paragraph

text: Ifa universal attitude is needed anywhere at all in architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: then it is in town planning. Apart from a wide survey, a far-
label: Paragraph

text: sighted point of view, there can be no urban order. Periods
label: Paragraph

text: incapable of arriving at a consistent outlook on the world are
label: Paragraph

text: also incapable of carrying out the kind of town planning that
label: Paragraph

text: goes beyond mere patchwork. And armies of specialists are no
label: Paragraph

text: help when what is missing is a universal attitude covering the
label: Paragraph

text: whole of life.
label: Paragraph

text: On the contrary, specialists who lack the universal attitude are
label: Paragraph

text: incapable of grasping real relationships. Valuable and precise
label: Paragraph

text: as their work may be, its results will be limited and out of
label: Paragraph

text: balance — perhaps even harmful, since one task is overstressed
label: Paragraph

text: at the expense of another. Periods which depend on specialists
label: Paragraph

text: are incapable of successful town planning. Whal happens in
label: Paragraph

text: such times is something like the case of a man who reads a
label: Paragraph

text: book, and from extreme exactitude never manages to get be-
label: Paragraph

text: yond the first. ten pages. He loses the meaning of the whole in
label: Paragraph

text: attending to the details. The situation nowadays is an anal-
label: Paragraph

text: ogous one. In spite of the existence of many conscientious
label: Paragraph

text: town-planning associations and of trained specialists in the
label: Paragraph

text: planning and administration of towns, there prevails a shock-
label: Paragraph

text: ing lack of direction and an inability to remove the most
label: Paragraph

text: obvious inconveniences.
label: Paragraph

text: The penalty cannot be evaded when, for a hundred years, there
label: Paragraph

text: has been almost nothing but chaos in town planning. Regula-
label: Paragraph

text: lions alone offer no solution, for the regulations also bear the
label: Paragraph

text: stamp of the men who make them: a new universal vision is
label: Paragraph

text: needed.
label: Paragraph

text: lt would be unreasonable to expect new solutions to town-
label: Paragraph

text: planning problems from a period like the nineteenth century.
label: Paragraph

text: A century which (especially in its later course) was so domi-
label: Paragraph

text: nated by the spirit of laissez-faire, and so much under the rule
label: Paragraph

text: of specialists. was no time for town planning, which by its
label: Paragraph

text: very nature must come out of broad vision and foresight.
label: Paragraph

text: There is no doubt that the charm of many of the personal
label: Paragraph

text: expressions and forms of living of the last century will be more
label: Paragraph

text: and more fully recognized in the near future. But its town
label: Paragraph

text: planning will not be included in this coming revaluation.
label: Paragraph

text: Our interest in town planning can be reduced to three ques-
label: Paragraph

text: tions: Was the highly developed late baroque art of town
label: Paragraph

text: planning continued during the nineteenth century? «What
label: Paragraph

text: arose to take its place afterwards? Finally, whal new solutions
label: Paragraph

text: has the twentieth century to offer?
label: Paragraph

text: In times when there is a universal vision resting on a long and
label: Paragraph

text: solid tradition, town planning is taken as a matter of course.
label: Paragraph

text: We have considered some eighteenth-century solutions which
label: Paragraph

text: were interesting for their farsightedness and for the feeling
label: Paragraph

text: for space which they manifest. Many of an amazingly high
label: Paragraph

text: quality are the work of anonymous architects, even of specu-
label: Paragraph

text: lators. It is important to notice that solutions which come out
label: Paragraph

text: of the universal vision of the eighteenth century still remain
label: Paragraph

text: valid long after the death of the society —- or the ideal of a
label: Paragraph

text: society — for which they were formulated, and after changes
label: Paragraph

text: in circumstance which the designers could never have fore-
label: Paragraph

text: seen. But when the vision of a period is predominately in-
label: Paragraph

text: lluenced by spectalists, the solutions arrived al do not even
label: Paragraph

text: satisfy the needs of the time of their creation.
label: Paragraph

text: The late baroque showed a magnificent power of dominating
label: Paragraph

text: outer space. This period was thoroughly aware of the different
label: Paragraph

text: relationships that held between one building and another and
label: Paragraph

text: between buildings and nature: between constructions and
label: Title

text: organisms.
label: Paragraph

text: The feeling from which baroque town planning sprang — one
label: Paragraph

text: made natural by its social life. - limited attention to the con-
label: Paragraph

text: nections between palatial residences and to the spatial treat-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of the beautiful plazas of the great towns.
label: Paragraph

text: Late baroque town planning is the expression of two-absolut-
label: Paragraph

text: isms: the first produced by the Counter Reformation, the
label: Paragraph

text: second by monarchy. All the constructions which benefited
label: Paragraph

text: from the great fund of experience of the period were built for
label: Paragraph

text: the Church, for the king, or for those who helped these two to
label: Paragraph

text: rule.
label: Paragraph

text: The lodgings of the common people did not enter into these
label: Paragraph

text: schemes; they were not thought of as presenling anv problem,
label: Paragraph

text: The people formed the invisible foundation and support of the
label: Paragraph

text: state; all that rose above the ground was meant, without
label: Paragraph

text: question, for the ruling class. People of great experience and
label: Paragraph

text: wide vision - - like Vauban, Louis XIV’s great military en.
label: Paragraph

text: gineer — saw the danger in a system which put such burdens
label: Paragraph

text: upon the people. But Vauban’s Projet d'une dizme royale
label: Paragraph

text: (1709) cost him the monarch’s favor by its assertion that
label: Paragraph

text: important,” Vauban continued, * in view of its numbers and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of their incomes) as well as the people.

text: The Rue de Rivoli of Napoleon I
label: Title

text: When Napoleon I commissioned Percier and Fontaine, the
label: Paragraph

text: founders of the Empire style, to design the Rue de Rivoli, the
label: Paragraph

text: main outlines of the design were established in advance by
label: Paragraph

text: existing conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: The Rue de Rivoli of Napoleon I, still the most beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: street in Paris, is not a rue corridor. It has only one wall, and
label: Paragraph

text: this faces upon the gardens of the Tuileries and, what is more
label: Paragraph

text: important, upon an avenue. The avenue had been laid out
label: Paragraph

text: under Louis XIV (as an eighteenth-century engraving by
label: Paragraph

text: Mariette plainly shows), and at first led to the royal stables
label: Paragraph

text: (fig. 247). These stables occupied the site upon which the
label: Paragraph

text: Rue de Rivoli was built.
label: Paragraph

text: The Place de la Concorde, where the Rue de Rivoli begins, was
label: Paragraph

text: built under Louis XV and Louis XVI, and the bridge over the
label: Paragraph

text: Seme was built just at the beginning of the Revolution, in
label: Paragraph

text: Louis XIV laid out the park, Louis XV the square, and Napo-
label: Paragraph

text: leon the street. It was quite typical of the building programs
label: Paragraph

text: of the period that Napoleon should have commanded the
label: Paragraph

text: building of a street (this was at the time of his consulate, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1801). The street was intended for the rich bourgeoisie and
label: Paragraph

text: offered a view of the royal gardens.
label: Paragraph

text: In marked contrast with the English practice of making busi-
label: Paragraph

text: ness and residential streets entirely separate, the Rue de
label: Paragraph

text: Rivoli was both in one.? Continuous pillared arcades pro-
label: Paragraph

text: tected shoppers from the weather and at the same time pre-
label: Paragraph

text: yented the shop fronts from diminishing the dignity of the
label: Paragraph

text: street. Placards and grocers’ shops were excluded. These
label: Paragraph

text: arcades continue the tradition of the seventeenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: Place des Vosges.
label: Paragraph

text: In working out their new task Percier and Fontaine used a
label: Paragraph

text: form which is as neutral as it is appealing (fig. 249). It goes
label: Paragraph

text: without saying that the houses were treated as a unit. To
label: Paragraph

text: preserve the effect, there are but few accents. The pillared
label: Paragraph

text: arches of the ground floor are in strict alignment; the bal-
label: Paragraph

text: conies of the first, third, and attic floors are continuous; the
label: Paragraph

text: walls are smooth-surfaced.
label: Paragraph

text: The Rue de Rivoli of the time of Napoleon I is a part of the
label: Paragraph

text: late baroque tradition (fig. 248). Its single row of houses per-
label: Paragraph

text: mits as free an outlook as the brothers Adam provided for the
label: Paragraph

text: occupants of their splendid Adelphi Terrace, built in 1768,
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the banks of the Thames. The Rue de Rivoli, at
label: Caption

text: this stage of its development, inspired John Nash and his
label: Paragraph

text: employer, the Prince Regent, in their plans for the laying out
label: Paragraph

text: of Regent’s Park and its terraces.

text: Wandering through London, one frequently comes upon

label: Paragraph

text: We have seen that the fundamental requirement for town
label: Paragraph

text: planning is the maintenance of one controlling authority, with
label: Paragraph

text: no dispersion among independent owners of control over the
label: Paragraph

text: ground. But perhaps as important is the necessity for this
label: Paragraph

text: controlling authority to possess an instinct for town planning.
label: Paragraph

text: At the present time enormous blocks of residential or business
label: Paragraph

text: premises have been thrust into the beautiful late baroque
label: Paragraph

text: squares — Berkeley Square, for example — and are destroying
label: Paragraph

text: everything. Business is not alone the offender. The University
label: Paragraph

text: of London is steadily reducing the noblest district of the city
label: Paragraph

text: to insignificance. Various influential London groups have
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: TRANSFORMATION OF PARIS, 1853-68
label: Title

text: The London squares antedate the railroad; the transformation
label: Paragraph

text: of Paris, on the other hand, took place during the feverish
label: Paragraph

text: riddle years of the railway age. The London squares were
label: Paragraph

text: designed primarily to be lived in, with busy thoroughfares
label: Paragraph

text: excluded. Thus the traffic of London — at this period a city
label: Paragraph

text: three times as big as Paris — circled the Bloomsbury district
label: Paragraph

text: ata distance, and the same thing was true of many other sec-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of the town. Residential quarters were kept intact and
label: Paragraph

text: systematically isolated from traffic routes.
label: Paragraph

text: The situation in the Paris of Napoleon III was quite different.
label: Paragraph

text: One element dominates all others: the street, the “ cannon-
label: Paragraph

text: shot boulevard,” seemingly without an end. The great town
label: Paragraph

text: of the latter half of the nineteenth century, the metropolis of
label: Paragraph

text: the industrial era, suddenly takes its typical form in Paris
label: Paragraph

text: between 1850 and 1870. In no other city of this period do the
label: Paragraph

text: changes consequent upon the development of industry proceed
label: Title

text: with such impetus.
label: Paragraph

text: Paris in the First Half of the Nineteenth Century
label: Title

text: A large map of Paris hung on the wall of Napoleon ITI’s study
label: Caption

text: at Saint-Cloud. With his own hand— “his own august
label: Paragraph

text: hand,’ Haussmann prefers to say — he plotted on it the alter-
label: Paragraph

text: ations he intended to make in the city. These proposed altera-
label: Paragraph

text: tions were marked out in red, blue, and green, in descending
label: Paragraph

text: order of urgency. For the most part, those sketched in green
label: Paragraph

text: were never executed.
label: Paragraph

text: The original and all but one of the copies later made of it were
label: Paragraph

text: lost in a fire. The surviving copy was found quite recently in
label: Caption

text: the library of the castle in Berlin by a French historian.?* The
label: Paragraph

text: King of Prussia had been presented with this copy by Napo-
label: Paragraph

text: leon ITI on the occasion of the German monarch’s visit to the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Exhibition of 1867 — the apogee of the Second Empire.

text: We have observed the interrelations since the seventeenth

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Haussmann stands as a symbol of the faith of the nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century in production.
label: Paragraph

text: It took Borromini nearly thirty years to erect a small church

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: created the great nincteenth-century city. The speed of the
label: Paragraph

text: sion which occasioned it.
